A dark morph so rare it was thought extinct for 33 years suddenly reappeared when two normal parents hatched a jet-black chick in captivity.
/wiki/Mississippi_kite: A graceful aerial hunter that catches grasshoppers and cicadas mid-flight, making it a farmer's best friend. Social flocks of over 10,000 have been recorded during migration to South America. Once a forest dweller, it has successfully colonized cities and now raises more chicks in urban backyards than in the wild.
/wiki/Crane_hawk: Equipped with unique double-jointed ankle bones that let it reach deep into tree cavities like a feathered lockpick, extracting hidden prey other raptors can't touch. This specialized hunter raids parrot nests and plucks bats from hollow trees, a trait shared only with Africa's harrier-hawks through convergent evolution.
/wiki/Snail_kite: Nearly extinct with fewer than 400 pairs in the 1990s, this specialist raptor rebounded to 3,000 birds by adapting to invasive snails—rapidly evolving larger beaks in just decades. Its deeply hooked beak is exclusively designed for extracting apple snails from their shells, making it one of the world's most specialized predators.
/wiki/Common_black_hawk: A mangrove specialist with an unusual taste for crustaceans, hunting land crabs and crayfish instead of typical hawk prey. Has naturally hybridized with red-shouldered hawks in California—a rare cross-genus pairing. Its distinctive piping call echoes through coastal swamps as it soars on very broad wings.
/wiki/Great_black_hawk: An incredibly rare vagrant to the US, with only one documented individual—a young bird that wandered from Mexico to Texas, then somehow ended up in Maine where it succumbed to frostbite during a snowstorm. Hunts on foot for everything from reptiles to hoatzin eggs, often raiding riverside nesting colonies with its distinctive piping call echoing through tropical forests.
/wiki/Roadside_hawk: Often the most common raptor across Latin America, this vocal hawk barely reaches the US as an occasional visitor to Texas. Has been documented attacking humans who venture too close to its nest, and preys on young monkeys with surprising regularity.
/wiki/Harris's_hawk: The only raptor that routinely hunts in cooperative packs like wolves, with up to seven birds working together to take down jackrabbits twice their weight. A dominance hierarchy led by the alpha female means multiple males may help raise a single nest of chicks, with young sometimes staying to assist for three years.
/wiki/White-tailed_hawk: This stocky raptor hovers motionless while scanning for prey, then swoops down on everything from rabbits to foot-long lizards. Known to gather at brushfires with other scavengers to catch fleeing animals, and ranks among the top predators of small monkeys in the tropics.
/wiki/Gray_hawk: Unusually agile for its genus, this short-winged raptor swoops down from high perches to snatch lizards and snakes with orange-taloned precision. Northern populations make epic spring migrations to breed in the Southwest, while tropical birds stay put year-round in their forest edge territories.
/wiki/Red-shouldered_hawk: This forest raptor's distinctive screaming call is so iconic that blue jays regularly imitate it to fool other birds. Despite losing 98% of California riparian habitat, it has adapted to hunt in suburban woodlands, dropping from treetops to snatch prey as large as pheasants.
/wiki/Broad-winged_hawk: Migrates in enormous flocks called "kettles" of thousands of birds, soaring up to 4,000 feet on thermals during journeys of up to 3,700 miles. Meticulously prepares meals by skinning frogs and snakes and plucking feathers from prey birds. During courtship, pairs hook their feet together mid-flight and spiral downward in dramatic aerial displays.
/wiki/Hawaiian_hawk: Once revered as Hawaiian royalty and featured in creation myths, this endemic raptor adapted from hunting flightless birds to preying on introduced rats and lizards. Fiercely territorial year-round, pairs nest in native forests where females aggressively guard chicks, refusing to let males approach except to deliver food.
/wiki/Short-tailed_hawk: A master of aerial ambush that hunts by "kiting" — hovering motionless in the wind before plummeting down in a stair-step dive. Despite hours of effort, this patient predator succeeds in only 11% of its hunting attempts, making each meal hard-won.
/wiki/Swainson's_hawk: Migrates up to 7,100 miles from Canada to Argentina—the second-longest journey of any North American raptor. Known as the "grasshopper hawk" for its voracious appetite for locusts, gathering in spectacular flocks of hundreds as entire populations funnel through Panama. The ancestor of the Galápagos hawk, which diverged just 300,000 years ago.
/wiki/Zone-tailed_hawk: A master of deception that mimics the flight style of turkey vultures—soaring with wings held in a dihedral and rocking side to side—to blend into flocks and sneak up on unsuspecting prey. This clever hawk even shares the vulture's blackish plumage and wing pattern, allowing it to hide in plain sight while hunting live animals that wouldn't flee from scavengers.
/wiki/Red-tailed_hawk: The most commonly captured hawk for falconry in the US, this opportunistic predator can thrive everywhere from deserts to cities. So adaptable it survives on island diets of crabs and lizards when mammals aren't available, and its recognizable silhouette is protected across North America by international treaty.
/wiki/Rough-legged_hawk: One of the only large hawks that regularly hovers in place like a hummingbird, watching for voles and lemmings below. Its feet are feathered all the way to the talons as an adaptation to brutal Arctic winters. Can see ultraviolet scent marks left by rodents, giving it a secret hunting advantage invisible to human eyes.
/wiki/Ferruginous_hawk: The largest hawk in North America, often mistaken for an eagle due to its massive size and royal bearing. Feathers cover its legs all the way to its talons, and it boasts the most robust feet of any buteo hawk worldwide. Soars over open prairies with wings held in a dihedral, hunting from the air or waiting in ambush outside prey burrows.
/wiki/Long-legged_buzzard: Despite its eagle-like silhouette and impressive wingspan rivaling the largest buzzards at nearly 5 feet, this sluggish raptor prefers to waddle on the ground or perch openly for hours. Can hover for extended periods while hunting rodents across four distinct color morphs ranging from pale sandy to all-black. Takes up to 3 years to reach adult plumage, making first breeding a patient affair.
/wiki/Common_buzzard: Europe's most common daytime raptor, with plumage so wildly variable that individuals range from nearly pure white to solid black-brown. Genetic studies reveal this highly successful predator is a surprisingly young species, having diverged from its relatives only 300,000 years ago. Closely related to North America's red-tailed hawk, occupying the exact same ecological niche on different continents.
/wiki/Eastern_buzzard: A powerful raptor of East Asia that some scientists still debate whether to classify as its own species or a subspecies of the common buzzard. Soars over the mountains and forests of Japan, China, and Mongolia, with some populations migrating to Southeast Asia when winter arrives.
/wiki/Barn_owl: Hunts in total darkness using hearing so acute it can pinpoint a mouse under snow from sound alone. Mates for life and produces an eerie shrieking call instead of the typical hoot. Its heart-shaped face acts as a satellite dish, funneling the faintest sounds to asymmetrically placed ears.
/wiki/Oriental_scops-owl: When threatened, this yellow-eyed owl freezes with half-closed eyes in a bizarre defensive display. Its distinctive "tuk tok torok" call echoes through Asian forests, where it nests in the cavities of Mahua trees. Comes in grey and rufous color morphs, with many intermediate forms blurring the line between them.
/wiki/Flammulated_owl: Named for flame-like facial markings, this tiny migratory owl breaks the mold by nesting in loose colonies and feeding almost exclusively on insects. Despite weighing less than a deck of cards, it boasts a 14-inch wingspan that allows rapid, agile flight through forest canopies.
/wiki/Puerto_Rican_owl: Uniquely bare-legged among owls, this nocturnal hunter's guttural trill sounds remarkably like a toad. Its closest relative is surprisingly the migratory flammulated owl of North America, despite being confined to a Caribbean island for millennia.
/wiki/Whiskered_screech-owl: This tiny nocturnal hunter uses exceptional hearing to pinpoint prey in total darkness, swooping down from perches or snatching insects mid-flight. Nearly identical to its western cousin but distinguished by heavier breast barring, it delivers a haunting series of eight "boo" notes that echo through mountain coffee plantations and oak forests.
/wiki/Western_screech-owl: A master of disguise with streaky brown and gray plumage, this tiny nocturnal hunter can take down prey as large as mallard ducks despite weighing only 5 ounces. Males sing bounce songs at frequencies 30% lower than females, and motion-activated cameras have caught them eagerly scavenging roadkill. Their excellent hearing and night vision make them deadly ambush predators that swoop from perches onto unsuspecting mice, bats, and even small trout.
/wiki/Eastern_screech-owl: Despite its name, this owl doesn't screech at all. A master of urban adaptation, it thrives in busy neighborhoods and has been found nesting on street lights in town squares, hunting introduced house sparrows and mice that follow human development.
/wiki/Great_horned_owl: One of the earliest nesting raptors in North America, this apex predator crushes prey with over 300 pounds per square inch of talon pressure—rivaling a golden eagle. Silent flight and asymmetrical ears allow it to hunt in total darkness, while fully feathered feet protect against everything from Arctic cold to desert heat.
/wiki/Snowy_owl: One of the few owls that hunts during the day, this Arctic predator's entire breeding success depends on lemming populations. A nomadic wanderer that rarely nests in the same place twice, it can lay up to 11 eggs and once roamed as far south as Italy during the ice age.
/wiki/Northern_hawk_owl: Unlike nearly all other owls, this diurnal hunter is active only during daylight hours and resembles a hawk in both appearance and behavior. It fearlessly defends its nest and can spot voles beneath snow from hundreds of feet away, swooping down from spruce perches in open boreal forests.
/wiki/Northern_pygmy-owl: Sports fake eyespots on the back of its head to fool predators while hunting during the day—unusual for an owl. Males perch atop the tallest conifers to issue ventriloquistic calls that confuse observers trying to locate them. Despite being tiny, occasionally takes down prey as large as California quail.
/wiki/Ferruginous_pygmy-owl: Sports fake eyes on the back of its head to deter predators while hunting. Despite being tiny, it's often mobbed by groups of up to 40 birds who recognize it as a threat. This fierce daylight hunter can imitate woodpecker flight patterns and whistles in E flat to communicate.
/wiki/Elf_owl: The world's smallest and lightest owl nests in saguaro cactus cavities and feigns death when captured, giving it a chance to escape predators. This sparrow-sized hunter removes scorpion stingers before eating them and emits puppy-like calls at dawn and dusk.
/wiki/Burrowing_owl: Unlike most owls, this long-legged hunter is active during the day and can sprint after prey on foot. When threatened in its burrow, it mimics a rattlesnake's warning sounds to scare off predators. Lines its underground nest with cattle dung to control temperature and attract insect prey.
/wiki/Mottled_owl: Shows the most extreme sexual dimorphism of any owl species, with females dramatically larger than males. A nighttime hunter with silent wings that swoops down on prey ranging from bats to beetles. First recorded in the US in 1983, it remains an exceptionally rare visitor from Central and South America.
/wiki/Spotted_owl: A nocturnal hunter of old-growth forests now being aggressively displaced by its larger cousin, the barred owl, with the two species occasionally hybridizing to create "sparred owls." Lives up to 17 years and can survive on a diet that's over 30% flying squirrels, swooping silently from perches up to 200 feet high.
/wiki/Barred_owl: An invasive predator whose westward expansion now threatens the endangered spotted owl through competition and interbreeding. Features specialized silent flight thanks to comb-like wing feathers, and eyes packed with rod cells that can see in almost complete darkness. Males can be a third lighter than females, making this one of the most sexually dimorphic owls in North America.
/wiki/Great_gray_owl: The world's longest owl by length, though much of its impressive size is an illusion created by fluffy feathers concealing a surprisingly light body. Its massive facial disc acts as a sound-focusing satellite dish, allowing it to detect prey moving beneath deep snow. Despite once being thought to require cold climates, populations now thrive in areas where summer temperatures exceed 100°F.
/wiki/Long-eared_owl: A nomadic ghost that doesn't build its own nest, instead squatting in abandoned crow homes and roosting communally with others of its kind. Despite having prominent ear tufts, they're not ears at all—likely used to signal mood and intent to other owls. Focuses its diet almost exclusively on voles, making it one of nature's most specialized rodent hunters.
/wiki/Stygian_owl: Named for the dark River Styx of Greek mythology, this blackish owl hunts bats in the night sky—a feat rarely accomplished by other owls. Surprisingly skips rodents entirely in favor of roosting birds, sometimes taking prey as large as itself, and even preys on venomous Hispaniolan solenodons.
/wiki/Short-eared_owl: Hunts in broad daylight with floppy, moth-like wingbeats just feet above the ground, swooping down on voles with talons-first precision. When threatened at the nest, this ground-nesting owl fakes a broken wing to lure predators away from its young. Found on every continent except Antarctica and Australia, making it one of the world's most widespread birds.
/wiki/Boreal_owl: So elusive and nocturnal that humans rarely glimpse it in the wild, this tiny predator hunts in near-silent flight through the taiga. Despite its small stature, it fearlessly takes down prey including flying squirrels and chipmunks, though larger owls often turn the tables and make it their meal.
/wiki/Northern_saw-whet_owl: One of North America's smallest owls, its feathers glow neon pink under UV light thanks to special pigments. Can hunt in complete darkness using asymmetrical ears that pinpoint prey with incredible precision, swooping down from high perches to catch mice and voles by sound alone.
/wiki/Northern_boobook: This hawk-like owl spots prey from a perch and swoops down to snatch insects and small birds mid-flight with its yellow talons. Despite being Japan's most common breeding owl, it remains so elusive that nests are practically impossible to find and sites are rarely reused. Males begin claiming territories in January, serenading mates with deep ho-ho calls that echo only during breeding season.
/wiki/Elegant_trogon: The northernmost trogon in the world, this metallic-green beauty communicates through tail movements as well as calls, raising its copper-tinted tail to signal dominance or warn predators they've been spotted. Gnaws nest cavities in trees and hovers like a hummingbird to pluck berries mid-flight despite being reluctant to fly any real distance.
/wiki/Eared_quetzal: Named for wispy hair-like ear plumes rarely seen in the field, this iridescent jewel plucks prey and fruit while hovering mid-flight. Studies reveal it's actively repelled by bright colors on human observers—including its own species' red and blue plumage—defying expectations about color attraction in birds.
/wiki/Eurasian_hoopoe: When threatened, nestlings spray intruders with foul-smelling secretions that reek of rotting meat while hissing like snakes—a defense so effective it deters most predators. This cinnamon-crested bird can open its bill while probing underground thanks to specialized head muscles, detecting insect larvae up to 150mm long. Recorded once in Alaska's Yukon Delta in 1975, making it an extraordinary vagrant from its Eurasian range.
/wiki/Puerto_Rican_tody: This voracious emerald hunter can lower its body temperature by 14°C to save energy, spending 33% less than similar birds. Nests in burrows it excavates in earthen banks, often assisted by previous offspring who help raise the next generation. Despite being named 'mexicanus,' it never set foot in Mexico—the original naturalist simply wrote down the wrong country.
/wiki/Common_kingfisher: Must consume 60% of its body weight daily in fish, which it catches by diving with special visual adaptations to see underwater. Fiercely territorial birds will grab intruders by the beak and attempt to drown them. Excavates tunnel nests up to 90cm deep into riverbanks, with the burrow eventually becoming littered with fish bones and regurgitated pellets.
/wiki/Pacific_kingfisher: Revered as sacred by Pacific Islanders, this patient hunter sits motionless on exposed perches before gliding down to snatch crabs, lizards, and even small birds. It pounds larger prey against branches to subdue them, then regurgitates indigestible remains as pellets like a tiny owl.
/wiki/Guam_kingfisher: Extinct in the wild since 1986 after introduced brown tree snakes decimated the population, this brilliantly colored kingfisher now survives only in captive breeding programs with fewer than 200 individuals remaining. Males sport rusty-cinnamon plumage while females are white below, and both parents defend permanent territories as devoted family units.
/wiki/Collared_kingfisher: Perches motionless for extended periods before gliding down to snatch prey, then pounds larger victims against branches to subdue them. Found across an enormous range from the Red Sea to Polynesia, this adaptable hunter tackles everything from crabs and lizards to occasional small birds and mice. Regurgitates indigestible remains as pellets after swallowing prey whole.
/wiki/Mariana_kingfisher: Endemic to the Northern Mariana Islands, this vibrant tropical kingfisher was only recently recognized as its own species after being lumped with the collared kingfisher. Despite its name suggesting fish-eating prowess, it thrives inland in forests and plantations far from water.
/wiki/Ringed_kingfisher: This fish-hunting aerial acrobat can perch for hours watching the water before plunging in for the kill. Males perform elaborate courtship displays by circling above water and offering fish gifts to potential mates. With a massive bill and rattling call louder than its cousin the belted kingfisher, it's slowly expanding its range northward from the Rio Grande.
/wiki/Belted_kingfisher: This fish-hunting expert exhibits rare reverse sexual dimorphism—the females are more colorful than males. Excavates long upward-sloping tunnels in riverbanks, possibly engineered so air pockets can save drowning chicks during floods. Its loud rattling call echoes across waterways as it plunges headfirst from perches to snatch prey.
/wiki/Amazon_kingfisher: This shaggy-crested diver excavates tunnels over 5 feet long into riverbanks, with males and females trading incubation shifts day and night. Despite ranging from Mexico to Argentina, it's only a rare vagrant to the US, appearing occasionally in Texas.
/wiki/Green_kingfisher: This tiny emerald hunter defends feeding territories fiercely from its own kind while ignoring other kingfisher species entirely. Strikes together two pebbles with its call, then dives from perches to snatch fish up to three inches long. Pairs excavate meter-long burrows in riverbanks where both parents share incubation duties.
/wiki/Oriental_dollarbird: Named for the distinctive pale blue coin-shaped spots that flash on its wings during flight, this aerial hunter perches bolt upright on high bare branches, darting out to snatch insects before returning to the exact same spot. Breeds in Australia and migrates to New Guinea, ranging as far as Japan and India but never reaching American shores.
/wiki/Eurasian_wryneck: Can twist its head nearly 180 degrees and mimics a hissing snake when threatened—behavior so unsettling it inspired the word "jinx" from medieval witchcraft. Feeds almost exclusively on ants, flicking them up with lightning-fast tongue strikes while hopping along the ground. The only European woodpecker that migrates long distances, traveling from temperate Eurasia to tropical Africa each year.
/wiki/Lewis's_woodpecker: Named after explorer Meriwether Lewis, this crow-like woodpecker breaks all the rules by catching insects mid-flight and storing nuts for winter like a squirrel. With broader wings than typical woodpeckers, it flies with slow, sluggish flaps and boldly perches in the open rather than hiding in heavy cover.
/wiki/Puerto_Rican_woodpecker: The only woodpecker endemic to Puerto Rico, this species drills nest cavities that become vital real estate for other rare island birds like the yellow-shouldered blackbird. Males sport bills 18% longer than females and occasionally supplement their insect diet with scorpions, geckos, and tiny tree frogs.
/wiki/Red-headed_woodpecker: One of only four woodpecker species that hoards food, stuffing insects and nuts into tree crevices for later. So territorial it will destroy the nests and eggs of other birds. Despite a 65% population decline over 40 years, it bounced back to stable status by 2018.
/wiki/Acorn_woodpecker: A master hoarder that drills thousands of individual holes in dead trees to create elaborate acorn pantries defended by family groups of up to 15 birds. Lives in complex polygynandrous societies where multiple brothers mate with multiple sisters, and sometimes nests in fall—a rare behavior in birds—to capitalize on the acorn harvest.
/wiki/Gila_woodpecker: A desert architect that drills nest cavities into giant saguaro cacti, creating homes that eventually become sought-after real estate for elf owls and dozens of other species. This opportunistic omnivore raids hummingbird feeders for nectar and will even snatch eggs and baby birds from nests.
/wiki/Golden-fronted_woodpecker: A year-round resident that adjusts remarkably well to human development, thriving in both wild mesquite landscapes and suburban neighborhoods. Males sport a distinctive red crown and golden nape, while both sexes hammer out nest cavities in everything from living trees to utility poles. Often raises two broods per season, with pairs staying together throughout the year and defending their territory even when not nesting.
/wiki/Red-bellied_woodpecker: Despite its name, the red belly is barely visible—but don't miss the loud drumming on aluminum gutters and transformer boxes to attract mates. A major predator of invasive emerald ash borers, removing up to 85% of larvae from a single infested tree.
/wiki/Williamson's_sapsucker: Males and females look so different that 19th century scientists classified them as separate species for decades. Excavates a fresh nesting cavity each year while feeding primarily on conifer sap, with fewer than 500 individuals breeding in rapidly disappearing Canadian larch forests.
/wiki/Yellow-bellied_sapsucker: Drills precise rows of holes in tree bark to create sap wells, then guards these sweet feeding stations from other animals. Uses dead trees as percussion instruments for long-distance communication, drumming in rapid bursts that can last up to five seconds. The hungrier chicks beg louder and get fed first, with their calls audible from over 100 meters away.
/wiki/Red-naped_sapsucker: Drills precise rows of holes in tree bark to create sap wells, then returns to feast on the sweet liquid and insects trapped in it. So closely related to its red-breasted cousin that hybrids between the two species are remarkably common. Creates nest cavities that are reused by numerous other cavity-nesting species, making it a keystone architect of forest ecosystems.
/wiki/Red-breasted_sapsucker: Drills precise horizontal rows of holes in living trees to farm sap, returning repeatedly to harvest the flow along with trapped insects. Its methodical drilling can actually kill trees over time, but creates feeding opportunities for other species like hummingbirds that follow its movements. The tongue is specially adapted with stiff hairs for collecting sap like a tiny brush.
/wiki/American_three-toed_woodpecker: A forest firefighter's companion that actively seeks out beetle-infested trees and burn zones, turning dead forests into thriving ecosystems. Sports only three toes instead of the usual four, and excavates a brand new nest cavity every single year. Often outcompeted by its close relative, the black-backed woodpecker, when their territories overlap.
/wiki/Black-backed_woodpecker: A burnt-forest specialist that thrives where wildfires strike, feasting on outbreaks of wood-boring beetles in charred trees. Unlike nearly all other woodpeckers, this species has only three toes on each foot instead of four.
/wiki/Great_spotted_woodpecker: Drums on trees at a blistering 10-16 strikes per second—faster than any other woodpecker in its range. This pied specialist can chisel through bark to raid other birds' nests for eggs and chicks, or extract seeds from pinecones with surgical precision. Extirpated from Ireland by deforestation, wandering juveniles recently recolonized the island after traveling up to 1,900 miles from their birthplace.
/wiki/Downy_woodpecker: North America's smallest woodpecker, yet a fierce agricultural ally that devours European corn borers—a pest costing over $1 billion in crop damage annually. Despite looking nearly identical to its larger hairy cousin, this is pure convergent evolution; the two species aren't closely related at all.
/wiki/Nuttall's_woodpecker: Named after naturalist Thomas Nuttall, this California native likely split from its Arizona cousin when Pleistocene glaciation dried out the land between them. Males and females take shifts incubating eggs—he works the night shift while she takes the day, with roles switching every 12 hours like clockwork.
/wiki/Ladder-backed_woodpecker: Named for the distinctive barred pattern on its back, this desert-adapted woodpecker excavates nest cavities in giant cacti when trees are scarce. Its chisel-like bill drills into tree trunks to extract insect larvae, but it also feeds on cactus fruit in arid environments.
/wiki/Red-cockaded_woodpecker: The only woodpecker that excavates cavities exclusively in living pine trees, taking up to 3 years to carve out a home. Keeps resin flowing from sap wells around its cavity as a defense mechanism against rat snakes. Its abandoned homes become vital real estate for dozens of other species, making it a keystone architect of southern pine forests.
/wiki/Hairy_woodpecker: A spectacular example of convergent evolution, this woodpecker has evolved to look virtually identical to its smaller cousin despite not being closely related. A fierce ally to farmers, it preys on the European corn borer moth—a pest that costs US agriculture over $1 billion annually in losses.
/wiki/White-headed_woodpecker: Sports a striking black body with white head in a reverse tuxedo look that breaks all woodpecker fashion rules. Southern populations evolved longer, stouter bills specifically to crack open the massive, spine-covered cones of Coulter pines. Males flash a subtle red patch on the back of their heads like a secret badge.
/wiki/Arizona_woodpecker: Recently split from its southern cousin Strickland's woodpecker, this Sky Island specialist inhabits isolated mountain ranges rising from the desert. Males sport a distinctive red patch on the nape while both sexes produce a sharp, squeaky keech call and a rattling series of descending notes.
/wiki/Northern_flicker: Unlike other woodpeckers, this ground-feeder hammers through soil to raid underground ant colonies, with ants making up 45% of its diet. Its tongue can shoot out 2 inches beyond its bill, and it sometimes drums on metal objects to declare territory as loudly as possible. Known by over 100 common names, many imitating its sustained laughing call.
/wiki/Gilded_flicker: A desert woodpecker that carves nest holes near the tops of towering saguaro cacti, triggering the plant to seal the cavity with hardened sap that forms a waterproof "boot." Distinguished from its northern cousin by its yellow underwings, it has evolved to thrive in one of North America's harshest environments.
/wiki/Pileated_woodpecker: Carves out massive rectangular holes in trees that become homes for dozens of other species, from owls to raccoons. Its drumming echoes through the forest at a deep, slow roll that can last three seconds. The largest woodpecker in North America, it inspired the appearance of Woody Woodpecker himself.
/wiki/Ivory-billed_woodpecker: The largest woodpecker in the United States, its chisel-tipped ivory bill can pry off tightly bound bark that no other species can touch, giving it exclusive access to wood-boring beetle larvae. Last definitively seen in 1944, this "Holy Grail bird" may already be extinct despite sporadic unconfirmed sightings and ongoing searches in Arkansas, Louisiana, and Florida.
/wiki/Collared_forest-falcon: A secretive hunter that pursues prey on foot through the forest floor, using owl-like hearing and a pronounced facial disk to detect victims in dense vegetation. Takes down prey ranging from tiny 20-gram frogs to adult turkeys weighing over 3 kilograms. Its distinctive low-frequency call sounds almost human-like and can be heard echoing through the canopy at dawn during breeding season.
/wiki/Crested_caracara: A bold opportunist that walks the ground like a vulture, pirates food from other raptors by relentlessly harassing them, and has even learned to follow trains and cars for discarded snacks. The second-largest falcon in the world by weight, it may be the sacred bird depicted in ancient Aztec codices that inspired Mexico's national symbol.
/wiki/Eurasian_kestrel: Can see ultraviolet light to track rodent urine trails from the sky, hovering motionless 35-65 feet above the ground while hunting. Consumes the equivalent of 4-8 voles per day, sometimes caching extras for later like a feathered meal prepper.
/wiki/American_kestrel: Despite its name and appearance, DNA reveals this colorful falcon is actually closer to peregrines than to true kestrels—a stunning case of convergent evolution. North America's smallest and most common falcon hunts by perching to ambush prey, conserving energy with flight muscles that make up only 12% of its body weight compared to 20% in stronger-flying cousins. Sports fake eye-spots on the back of its head to fool attackers into thinking it's always watching.
/wiki/Red-footed_falcon: A colonial falcon that doesn't build its own nest, instead squatting in abandoned corvid homes while breeding. Males are striking blue-grey with crimson legs and undertail, while breeding pairs engage in frequent copulation sessions interspersed with joint nest inspections. Found just once in North America in 2004, this Eurasian wanderer has suffered a 90% population crash in parts of its range due to persecution.
/wiki/Amur_falcon: Undertakes one of nature's most epic journeys, migrating in massive flocks from Siberia across the Arabian Sea to Africa—a feat aided by feeding on dragonflies mid-ocean. In 2012, mass trapping in India sparked a conservation campaign that fitted birds with satellite transmitters to track their incredible 13,000-mile round trip.
/wiki/Merlin_(bird): A swift aerial hunter that specializes in taking down birds up to quail-sized in flight. Once called the 'pigeon hawk,' this pint-sized falcon has adapted so well to city life that some urban populations have stopped migrating altogether. Despite sharing a name with the legendary wizard, this bird's name comes from Old French and has no connection to Arthurian lore.
/wiki/Eurasian_hobby: This aerial acrobat snatches dragonflies from the air and devours them mid-flight while soaring in lazy circles. So swift and agile it can catch swallows and swifts on the wing, triggering distinctive alarm calls from birds that know to flee. Transfers prey from talons to beak without landing, eating breakfast while gliding through the sky.
/wiki/Aplomado_falcon: This slender falcon hunts with accipiter-like determination, cooperating in pairs to flush prey and fearlessly pursuing small birds into heavy cover. In Brazil, they've learned to follow maned wolves, snatching up birds startled by the wolves' footsteps. Females occasionally take down prey larger than themselves, including cattle egrets twice their weight.
/wiki/Gyrfalcon: The largest falcon in the world, prized by hunters for centuries, exists in dramatic color morphs ranging from pure white to charcoal black. Can catch ptarmigan and waterfowl mid-flight, and a single clutch may produce chicks of four completely different colors. Females can weigh twice as much as males, with the largest specimens tipping scales at nearly 6 pounds.
/wiki/Peregrine_falcon: The fastest animal on Earth, tucking into a teardrop-shaped dive called a stoop that generates enough force to kill prey on impact. Once nearly extinct due to DDT, it now thrives in cities worldwide, nesting on skyscrapers and feasting on pigeons.
/wiki/Prairie_falcon: An arid-adapted cousin of the peregrine that evolved proportionally larger eyes to spot scarce prey across the harsh desert. Built lighter but more aggressive than its famous relative, it will crash through dense cover and relentlessly pursue quarry up to its own weight. The only large falcon native exclusively to North America.
/wiki/Tanimbar_corella: This tiny genius of a cockatoo can spontaneously craft tools, solve five-part mechanical locks, and resist eating its favorite food for up to 80 seconds to get an even better reward. One famous individual named Figaro even figured out how to cheat intelligence tests by using sticks as levers. Thanks to illegal pet trade following devastating logging in the 1970s, more now exist in captivity than in their native Indonesian islands.
/wiki/Sulphur-crested_cockatoo: This brilliant mimic has learned to open garbage bins in Sydney by watching other cockatoos, with the technique spreading through imitation across the city. Can live over 100 years in captivity and spontaneously dances to music with unique choreographed moves. Produces a fine powder instead of oil to waterproof its feathers.
/wiki/White_cockatoo: When startled, this all-white bird unfurls a dramatic semicircular crest like an umbrella. Endemic to a handful of Indonesian islands, it produces a talcum-like powder from its feathers and can live over 60 years in captivity. Thousands are still illegally smuggled each year despite protective laws, with trappers once exceeding government quotas by 18 times.
/wiki/Monk_parakeet: The only parrot species that builds massive communal stick nests instead of nesting in tree holes, with colonies creating apartment-complex structures the size of a small car. Feral populations develop distinct vocal "dialects" between groups, with different accents documented even within single metropolitan areas like Milford, Connecticut. Occasionally recruits helper birds—often its own grown offspring—to assist with feeding chicks.
/wiki/Carolina_parakeet: America's only native parrot east of Texas, this bright green bird with a golden head was likely poisonous from eating toxic cocklebur seeds—cats reportedly died from eating them. The last one died in 1918 in the same Cincinnati Zoo cage that held Martha, the final passenger pigeon, four years earlier.
/wiki/Eupsittula_canicularis: This clever bird excavates nest cavities directly into arboreal termite mounds, waiting a week after digging for the termites to seal off the damage before moving in. Nomadic flocks of several hundred can cause serious damage to crops, though the species faces its own threat from illegal trapping for the pet trade. Both parents share excavation duties using only their beaks, often causing the entire termite nest to eventually collapse.
/wiki/Brown-throated_parakeet: A tenacious crop raider that excavates its nest inside living termite mounds, this chattering parakeet gets up to 70% of its food from human agriculture. So abundant it's considered a significant pest to maize and fruit crops, yet pairs communicate by calling in flight to coordinate foraging flocks.
/wiki/Nanday_parakeet: Originally from South America, escaped pet populations have colonized multiple U.S. states, forming loud communal roosts of feral parrots. Distinguished by its striking black facial mask, this clever bird can learn to talk and perform tricks. Its powerful beak and energetic personality make it both a charismatic companion and a notorious agricultural pest in its native range.
/wiki/Green_parakeet: This noisy Mexican native has mysteriously colonized the Rio Grande Valley—whether by escape or natural expansion remains unknown. Notorious crop raiders that nest in tree cavities, caves, and even cliff faces, these social parrots fill the air with harsh screeches and chattering calls. Their cheeks sparkle with distinctive red speckles that vary from bird to bird.
/wiki/Puerto_Rican_parakeet: So unafraid of gunshots that it became tragically easy prey for hunters who wiped it out by 1882. This gregarious crop-raider's loud, continuous calling and fearless feeding habits in farmers' fields sealed its fate, with only three preserved specimens remaining today.
/wiki/Hispaniolan_parakeet: This green parrot with striking red wing markings can thrive from sea level to nearly 10,000 feet elevation. Despite adapting well to cities like Santo Domingo, persecution as a crop pest and illegal trapping have reduced its population to perhaps only 1,500 mature individuals. Once considered the same species as the now-extinct Puerto Rican parakeet that vanished from Mona Island.
/wiki/Mitred_parakeet: An escaped cage bird turned wild colonist, this noisy parrot now thrives in American cities with flocks of up to 2000 birds. Known for its piercing alarm call, it's been dubbed a 'watch bird' by owners who appreciate its ear-splitting warnings. In south Florida alone, it feeds on 34 different plant species while nesting almost exclusively on human structures.
/wiki/Red-masked_parakeet: Escaped pets that formed thriving wild colonies in San Francisco and beyond, famously featured in The Wild Parrots of Telegraph Hill. Considered the best talkers of all conures, these bright green birds with red heads have successfully colonized cities thousands of miles from their South American homeland.
/wiki/Thick-billed_parrot: This nomadic mountain parrot crosses vast distances daily between sleeping and feeding ranges, and deals with deep snow by hanging upside-down to access pine cones on snow-covered branches. Once relied on nest holes created by the now-extinct imperial woodpecker, the world's largest woodpecker. Historical flocks of over 1,000 birds would feed each other from their crops and preen socially, producing calls resembling eerie human laughter.
/wiki/White-winged_parakeet: This escaped cage bird has colonized American cities thousands of miles from its Amazon home, thriving in places like Miami and Los Angeles. Forms massive communal roosts after breeding season and will happily raid bird feeders alongside native species. So adaptable it switched from eating fruit and seeds to blossoms and nectar in its new urban territories.
/wiki/Yellow-chevroned_parakeet: An escaped cage bird turned thriving city dweller, this South American native eats clay and termite nests to supplement its diet with essential minerals for egg production. More successful than its close relatives in North American cities, it forms massive communal roosts after breeding season.
/wiki/White-fronted_parrot: The smallest of the Amazon parrots and one of only three species where males sport bright red shoulder patches while females have green ones. Can mimic 30-40 different sounds and may live over 50 years, often forming devoted bonds with their human companions.
/wiki/Hispaniolan_parrot: First described by Spanish historians in 1535 using the Taíno word "Higuaca," this white-foreheaded parrot forms lifelong pair bonds and reuses the same tree cavities for nesting each season. The aggressive xaxabis parrots were noted to attack larger higuacas in flocks, and unlike their cousins, they never learned to speak human words despite being incredibly vocal in their own language.
/wiki/Puerto_Rican_parrot: Plummeted from over 100,000 birds to just 13 individuals by 1975, making it one of the rarest birds on Earth. This cavity-nesting parrot was once so abundant that an entire valley was named after it, but agricultural expansion wiped out nearly all of Puerto Rico's virgin forests. The only native parrot left in Puerto Rico, it raises just one brood per year with chicks that take over two months to fledge.
/wiki/Orange-winged_parrot: Over 66,000 were captured for the pet trade in just four years, but some escapees turned the tables by establishing wild colonies in Miami and London. This noisy parrot roosts communally in massive flocks that fill the sky at dawn and dusk, and has even been caught hybridizing with other parrot species in the Canary Islands.
/wiki/Red-crowned_parrot: An endangered Mexican native that has found unexpected sanctuary in Los Angeles, where feral flocks now rival the entire wild population remaining in its homeland. These green parrots with crimson crowns can live over 70 years and return to the same tree cavity year after year to raise their young.
/wiki/Yellow-headed_parrot: Among the best talkers in the parrot world with an operatic singing voice, this vibrant amazon has been decimated by poaching—with up to 60% of captured birds dying before reaching the pet trade. Wild populations crashed 90% in just two decades, while introduced flocks now thrive in San Diego's coastal neighborhoods.
/wiki/Rose-ringed_parakeet: An escaped pet turned urban colonizer, this tropical parrot has mastered cold European winters and breeds farther north than any other parrot species. Flocks cause extensive damage to farmlands, flying miles to raid orchards, yet thrive in cities where they compete with bats for nest sites and mimic human speech with remarkable clarity.
/wiki/Blue-crowned_lorikeet: This vibrant green parrot sports a striking blue crown and a gradient belly that fades from red to purple. Despite nesting primarily in tree holes, it sometimes digs burrows into earthen banks like a tropical excavator. Travels in small flocks of 15 or fewer, feeding on nectar, pollen, and soft fruits across Pacific islands.
/wiki/Rosy-faced_lovebird: Female birds tear materials into strips, twisty-tie them onto their backs, and fly substantial distances to build nests. These escaped pets have established thriving colonies in scorching Arizona, where they've been observed clustering on air conditioner vents when temperatures exceed 104°F. Known for their adorable sleeping position of sitting side-by-side with faces turned toward each other.
/wiki/Masked_tityra: A bold black-and-white bird with a striking red eye-ring that has puzzled taxonomists for decades—shuffled between cotingas and flycatchers before finally earning its own family. The male sports a dapper black mask that stops short of the nape, while females wear more modest brownish tones.
/wiki/Gray-collared_becard: A taxonomic puzzle that has bounced between three different bird families as scientists debate its true evolutionary relationships. This small forest dweller ranges from lowland jungles to misty mountain forests across Central America, adapting to diverse elevations with ease.
/wiki/Rose-throated_becard: Males sport a distinctive rose-colored throat bib and build elaborate domed nests that dangle from high branches like ornaments. This taxonomic puzzle stumped scientists for decades—neither cotinga nor flycatcher, genetic evidence finally revealed it belongs to an entirely separate family. Eggs come in a rainbow of colors from purple to olive to pink, all mysteriously scrawled with intricate markings.
/wiki/Micronesian_myzomela: This tiny nectar-feeding powerhouse is so critical to its ecosystem that when it went extinct on Guam, the entire island was left without pollinators. Fiercely territorial despite its diminutive size, it aggressively defends flowering trees from intruders while fueling up on a 60% nectar, 40% insect diet.
/wiki/Cardinal_myzomela: Males flash brilliant scarlet plumage while using their long, curved bills to sip nectar from tropical flowers. Populations vanished entirely from Guam after the brown tree snake invasion, making this once-common honeyeater a cautionary tale of ecosystem disruption. This tiny acrobat measures just 5 inches but brings vibrant color to Pacific island gardens.
/wiki/Mao_(bird): This dusky honeyeater bobs its tail while hunting geckos and insects along tree trunks, feeding its single chick for over three months. Known for its haunting pre-dawn whistles and complex duets, it builds sticky cup nests and has mysteriously vanished from American Samoa despite still clinging to survival on nearby independent Samoan islands.
/wiki/Eastern_wattled-honeyeater: This species is endemic to Central Pacific islands including American Samoa, Fiji, Samoa, Tonga, and Wallis and Futuna, and does not occur in the continental United States or North America.
/wiki/Ashy_minivet: One of the few songbirds that molts its primary feathers twice yearly, this long-distance migrant travels farther than any other minivet species. Unlike its colorful relatives draped in yellows, oranges and reds, this bird sports only striking blacks, greys and whites.
/wiki/Black_drongo: Despite being only 11 inches long, this fearless aerial acrobat ruthlessly dive-bombs crows and hawks that enter its territory, earning it the nickname "king crow." Introduced to Pacific islands, it became so dominant it drove native species to extinction. Sometimes locks wings and beaks with its mate mid-courtship, tumbling together toward the ground.
/wiki/Rufous_fantail: A hyperactive acrobat of the rainforest understorey, this bird makes short, frequent flights while constantly fanning its blackish-brown tail. Males defend territory through intense, prolonged vocal 'battles' that can last for extended periods. Migrates thousands of miles between breeding grounds, undertaking an impressive seasonal journey from New Guinea to southeastern Australia.
/wiki/Northern_beardless-tyrannulet: This tiny tyrannulet feeds like a warbler but flycatches like its cousins, raising its erectile crest when alarmed or courting. Despite being nearly identical to its southern relative, the two species refuse to interbreed where their ranges overlap in Costa Rica, maintaining their separate identities.
/wiki/Greenish_elaenia: This tiny tropical flycatcher thrives even in heavily degraded forests where other species struggle to survive. Masters of aerial insect hunting, they snatch prey mid-flight with impressive precision despite their diminutive size.
/wiki/Small-billed_elaenia: A tiny South American flycatcher that has wandered north of the border just four times in recorded history. This tropical nomad feeds on insects and berries in forest canopies, making its rarity in the US all the more remarkable for birdwatchers hoping to add it to their life list.
/wiki/Caribbean_elaenia: First scientifically described from Martinique in 1760, this small flycatcher thrives even in heavily degraded habitats where other species struggle. Found across seven distinct subspecies throughout the Caribbean islands, it has adapted successfully to human-altered landscapes.
/wiki/White-crested_elaenia: A South American vagrant that made history with just two North American sightings—one in Texas in 2008 and another in Chicago in 2012. This migratory flycatcher travels thousands of miles from its Andean breeding grounds, with some individuals living over eight years while making these epic journeys twice annually.
/wiki/Dusky-capped_flycatcher: Distinguished by its sorrowful, whistling call that sounds like a descending "peeur," this aerial hunter snatches insects mid-flight from the middle branches of trees. When winter arrives, it supplements its diet with tropical fruits like gumbo-limbo berries, diversifying beyond its usual insect prey.
/wiki/Ash-throated_flycatcher: Unlike most flycatchers that return to the same perch, this desert dweller keeps moving after each aerial hunt. When insects are scarce, it switches to fruit—and occasionally kills small mammals and reptiles by bashing them against hard surfaces.
/wiki/Nutting's_flycatcher: Named after zoologist Charles Cleveland Nutting, this olive-brown flycatcher can be identified by its sharp 'weeep' call that sets it apart from nearly identical cousins. Nests in tree cavities and snatches insects from undergrowth with precision aerial maneuvers, though it won't turn down a berry snack when fruit is in season.
/wiki/Great_crested_flycatcher: Lines its tree cavity nest with shed snake skins—or plastic wrappers when reptilian decor isn't available. Despite being called a flycatcher, this treetop hunter actually prefers butterflies, beetles, and bees to flies, swooping down from high perches or even hovering to pluck prey from leaves.
/wiki/Brown-crested_flycatcher: This skulking insectivore announces its presence with a loud, commanding "come HERE, come HERE" call that echoes through open woodlands. Nests in tree cavities and occasionally snacks on gumbo-limbo fruit between hunting flights through the undergrowth.
/wiki/La_Sagra's_flycatcher: This Caribbean flycatcher catches insects on the wing from forest undergrowth and nests in tree cavities. Distinguished from look-alike relatives by its distinctive high-pitched 'wink' call. Occasionally wanders to southern Florida as a rare vagrant from its island home.
/wiki/Stolid_flycatcher: A Caribbean island specialist that hawks insects from exposed perches with lightning-quick aerial sallies. Despite its name suggesting a dull demeanor, this agile flycatcher dominates its tropical forest territory with aggressive territorial displays and distinctive dawn calls.
/wiki/Puerto_Rican_flycatcher: One of 22 species in its genus, this insect-hunting flycatcher is found nowhere else on Earth except the Puerto Rican archipelago. A classic tyrant flycatcher, it sallies from perches to snatch flying insects mid-air with impressive aerial precision.
/wiki/Great_kiskadee: One of the few fishing passerines, this bold flycatcher will dive into shallow water for prey and fearlessly mob raptors much larger than itself. Its onomatopoeic call sounds like "I see you well" in multiple languages, and it's so omnivorous it was introduced to Bermuda to control lizards—though it failed spectacularly.
/wiki/Social_flycatcher: A masterful aerial acrobat that performs elaborate maneuvers to catch insects mid-flight, and cleverly builds its nest near wasps, bees, or ants for protection. Has been observed foraging peacefully alongside marmosets in the undergrowth, possibly cooperating to flush hidden prey.
/wiki/Sulphur-bellied_flycatcher: A boldly streaked flycatcher whose call sounds exactly like a squeaky toy being repeatedly squeezed. Hawks insects from high perches in mountain canyons, then migrates thousands of miles to spend winters in the Andean foothills of South America.
/wiki/Piratic_flycatcher: A brazen nest pirate that doesn't build its own home, instead harassing much larger birds like oropendolas until they abandon their elaborate domed nests. Once the rightful owners flee, it tosses out their eggs and moves right in, raising its own family in stolen real estate.
/wiki/Variegated_flycatcher: An extremely rare South American wanderer with only ten confirmed North American records since 1977. This accidental vagrant has somehow strayed thousands of miles from its home range in Argentina, Brazil, and neighboring countries to appear unexpectedly across the continent from Maine to Washington.
/wiki/Crowned_slaty_flycatcher: This South American migrant holds the record for the longest scientific name of any bird species—a whopping fifteen syllables that literally translate to 'orange-black crested gray Tyrannus'. Travels thousands of miles between breeding grounds and the Amazon basin during austral winter, following seasonal food supplies across the continent.
/wiki/Tropical_kingbird: A fearless aerial acrobat that aggressively defends its territory against birds many times its size, including frigatebirds, hawks, and toucans. Launches from high perches to snatch insects mid-flight with impressive precision, sometimes hovering to pluck prey from leaves. With a population of 200 million strong, it's one of the most successful and widespread flycatchers in the Americas.
/wiki/Couch's_kingbird: So similar to its tropical cousin that they were considered the same species until 1979, this flycatcher can only be reliably identified by its raspier, more complex call. An aerial hunter that catches prey mid-flight before returning to its perch, it aggressively defends its nest by chasing away birds many times its size.
/wiki/Cassin's_kingbird: Performs an elaborate aerial dance with its mate each spring, hovering in unison over favorite perches with outstretched wings across several sites. Hawks insects from high vantage points and sports a distinctive white-edged tail that sets it apart from its western cousin.
/wiki/Thick-billed_kingbird: Named for its unusually stocky bill, this large tyrant flycatcher perches high in treetops and launches aerial attacks on flying insects. Its loud, whistled call echoes through desert canyons, while a hidden yellow crown patch remains one of nature's best-kept secrets.
/wiki/Western_kingbird: This fearless tyrant will attack hawks, humans, and even livestock to defend its territory, earning its royal title through sheer audacity. Hidden crimson crown feathers flash during courtship displays. Chicks often tumble from their cramped nests before they can fly, forced out by rapid growth and overcrowding.
/wiki/Eastern_kingbird: This fearless flycatcher aggressively defends its territory against birds many times its size, diving and mobbing ravens and crows to protect its nest. Its call sounds like an electric fence, and it sports a hidden red crown patch rarely glimpsed by observers.
/wiki/Gray_kingbird: Named for its rolling "pipiri" call, this fearless flycatcher aggressively defends its territory by mobbing hawks, caracaras, and even mammals many times its size. Perches high in exposed trees before sallying out to snatch bees, dragonflies, and wasps mid-flight.
/wiki/Loggerhead_kingbird: This Caribbean kingbird sports a secret crown patch of orange or yellow feathers hidden beneath its black cap, rarely glimpsed even by experienced birders. A versatile hunter that snatches flying insects mid-air while also feeding on berries and small lizards. Its squared tail with a distinctive buffy-white band makes it stand out among its tropical kingbird cousins.
/wiki/Scissor-tailed_flycatcher: Sports an extraordinarily long forked tail that can reach 15 inches, with males performing spectacular aerial courtship displays that stream their tail feathers behind them. Fiercely territorial despite its graceful appearance, aggressively defending nests while hawking insects mid-flight from exposed perches. Pre-migratory flocks can swell to 1,000 birds as they journey from Oklahoma to Panama.
/wiki/Fork-tailed_flycatcher: Despite weighing barely an ounce, this aerial acrobat can hit 65 mph in pursuit of flying insects, using its dramatically forked tail—up to three times its body length—to turn on a dime. Males perform swirling somersault displays during courtship and produce whistling sounds with their wings that differ so much between populations that scientists believe the species may be splitting in two.
/wiki/Tufted_flycatcher: A tropical highlander that breeds from Mexico to Ecuador but has only been spotted in the US a handful of times since 1991. Hunts flying insects from exposed perches like a pewee, vibrating its tail upon landing and returning obsessively to the same spot. Its dawn song is a blazingly fast cascade of notes that sounds like a musical hiccup.
/wiki/Olive-sided_flycatcher: An agile aerial hunter that undertakes one of the longest migrations of any flycatcher, traveling up to 7,000 miles between Alaska and Bolivia. Its distinctive song sounds like "Quick, three beers!" and it perches bolt-upright on dead snags while snatching insects mid-flight. Parents consume their chicks' fecal sacs during the first week as a nutritional supplement.
/wiki/Greater_pewee: Fearlessly defends its mountain territory by attacking hawks, jays, and squirrels despite being just 8 inches long. Its distinctive whistled song "jose maria" echoes through high-elevation pine forests, while its bright orange lower mandible serves as a field mark. Hawks insects from tall perches using its conspicuous crest and agile flight.
/wiki/Western_wood-pewee: A master aerial hunter that snatches flying insects mid-air from its perch, then returns to the same spot to wait for its next victim. So similar to its eastern cousin that scientists once thought they were the same species, until their distinctive buzzy "peeer" call gave away the truth.
/wiki/Eastern_wood-pewee: Named for its mournful 'pee-a'wee' whistle, this aerial hunter is virtually identical to its western cousin but gives itself away every time it sings. Despite migrating thousands of miles to South America each winter, it arrives fashionably late to breeding grounds—rarely before May—while similar species show up in March.
/wiki/Cuban_pewee: This small flycatcher sports a distinctive white crescent behind each eye instead of a typical eyering. Its haunting call is a long, descending whistle that echoes through Caribbean forests. Once considered part of a single widespread species, DNA analysis revealed it as unique to Cuba and the Bahamas.
/wiki/Hispaniolan_pewee: This Caribbean endemic lives exclusively on the island of Hispaniola, perching motionless before darting out to snatch flying insects mid-air with remarkable precision. Like other pewees, it returns to the same perch repeatedly, making it surprisingly easy to observe despite its drab plumage.
/wiki/Lesser_Antillean_pewee: This Caribbean flycatcher exists as multiple island populations that have diverged so distinctly that scientists debate whether they're actually three separate species. Perches quietly in the forest canopy, launching quick aerial sorties to snatch insects mid-flight before returning to the same spot.
/wiki/Yellow-bellied_flycatcher: Nests directly in sphagnum moss on the forest floor, an unusual choice for a flycatcher. Its rough "tse-berk" song echoes through northern spruce bogs where it hunts insects with quick aerial sallies from low perches.
/wiki/Acadian_flycatcher: An aerial acrobat so maneuverable it can hover mid-flight and even fly backward while snatching insects from the air. Despite being named for Acadia, this explosive 'peet-sa' singer isn't actually found there—a case of mistaken identity from when 15 similar species were thought to be one.
/wiki/Alder_flycatcher: So similar to its sibling species the willow flycatcher that they were considered one species until 1973, when scientists realized their songs were completely different. Throws its head back dramatically while singing its distinctive "fee-bee-o" call. Master gnat-catcher that flicks its tail upward while hunting insects mid-flight.
/wiki/Willow_flycatcher: Travels up to 8,000 km between breeding and wintering grounds, relying on song as the only way to distinguish it from its nearly identical cousin, the alder flycatcher. One endangered subspecies depends on beaver engineering to maintain its riparian habitat, while invasive saltcedar threatens populations across the Southwest.
/wiki/Least_flycatcher: Named for its distinctive "che-bec" call, this tiny flycatcher breeds in unusually tight clusters with neighbors, prioritizing proximity to other pairs over habitat quality for mysterious reasons. Males sing their two-syllable song up to 60 times per minute during spring mornings, with all males in an area seeming to perform in unison.
/wiki/Hammond's_flycatcher: Nearly impossible to distinguish from its lookalike cousins by sight alone, this tiny insect hunter is best identified by its distinctive hoarse call. On Vancouver Island, populations have evolved thicker bills in just a few thousand years to fill an ecological gap left by absent competitors.
/wiki/American_grey_flycatcher: While its cousins flick their tails upward, this flycatcher wags its tail downward—the only reliable way to tell it apart from nearly identical relatives. Waits patiently on low perches before launching aerial attacks on passing insects, hawking prey mid-flight with precision. Migration between breeding and wintering grounds takes seven weeks each way, with males arriving a week early to claim territory.
/wiki/American_dusky_flycatcher: Part of a notoriously confusing group of nearly identical species that experts struggle to tell apart by sight alone. This aerial acrobat catches insects mid-flight from strategic perches, then migrates thousands of miles across harsh southwestern deserts to winter in Mexico.
/wiki/Pine_flycatcher: An exceptionally rare visitor to the United States, with only a single confirmed sighting north of Mexico—a vagrant individual that appeared in Arizona's Santa Rita Mountains in 2016. This tiny mountain specialist inhabits high-elevation pine forests far south of the border, making any US appearance a major ornithological event.
/wiki/Western_flycatcher: Formerly split into two species based on subtle song differences, this aerial acrobat was re-lumped in 2023 after scientists discovered extensive hybridization across its range. Hawks flying insects mid-air with precision strikes, then plucks prey from leaves while hovering—playing a crucial role in controlling mosquito populations from the Pacific coast to the Rockies.
/wiki/Black_phoebe: A tireless aerial hunter that waits on perches before sallying out to snatch flying insects mid-air. Cements its mud nest under bridges and cliffs with such precision that it rarely strays far from water. Distinguished by its constant tail-wagging display, lowering and fanning its tail feathers in a signature motion.
/wiki/Eastern_phoebe: One of the first birds to arrive in spring and last to leave in fall, this tail-pumping flycatcher sings its own name: fee-bee. So adaptable to humans that it routinely builds mud nests on bridges and buildings, turning our structures into ideal nesting sites.
/wiki/Say's_phoebe: Named for naturalist Thomas Say, this barrel-chested flycatcher hovers like a kestrel while hunting and can be found thousands of miles out of range during migration. Nests under bridges and in abandoned mine shafts, sometimes breeding as far north as arctic Alaska despite its love of arid deserts.
/wiki/Vermilion_flycatcher: A striking exception among its drab flycatcher relatives, the male blazes bright vermilion red while engaging in dramatic courtship flights high above the canopy. Despite being socially monogamous, both sexes frequently engage in extra-pair copulation and females sometimes lay eggs in other birds' nests.
/wiki/Black-capped_vireo: The only vireo where males and females look completely different, this tiny songbird was saved from extinction through intensive cowbird control programs. Successfully delisted in 2018 after military bases became unlikely conservation heroes, proving that tanks and endangered birds can coexist.
/wiki/White-eyed_vireo: Uses spider webs like construction materials to attach its grass-lined nest to tree branches. Sings a distinctive six to seven note phrase that always starts and ends with a sharp 'chick.' Nearly went extinct in Bermuda after 8 million cedar trees were lost in the 1940s.
/wiki/Thick-billed_vireo: Both parents share egg-sitting duties in their grass-lined cup nest tucked into tropical shrubs. Sports a distinctive yellow partial "spectacle" just above its thick bill, giving it a scholarly appearance. Its rapid six to seven note song starts and ends with a sharp chick, slightly harsher than its white-eyed cousin.
/wiki/Cuban_vireo: Named after pioneering Cuban naturalist Juan Gundlach, this endemic island songbird thrives in habitats ranging from pristine dry forests to heavily degraded landscapes. A testament to adaptability, it continues to persist even as Cuba's native forests face ongoing transformation.
/wiki/Puerto_Rican_vireo: Known locally as "bien-te-veo" or "see-you-well" after its distinctive call, this tiny insectivore hunts everything from cicadas to small lizards. Suffered dramatic population crashes in the 1970s-90s when invasive shiny cowbirds parasitized its nests, laying eggs for the vireo to raise as its own.
/wiki/Bell's_vireo: Nearly extinct in 1986 with just 300 pairs remaining, this dull olive songbird has staged a remarkable six-fold comeback thanks to habitat protection efforts. Named after John Graham Bell who traveled the Missouri River with Audubon, it fearlessly defends its well-camouflaged nest against intruders despite being parasitized by cowbirds.
/wiki/Gray_vireo: The only vireo that twitches its tail like a gnatcatcher, making it easy to identify but hard to spot in dense brush. So skulking and secretive that it frequently abandons its nest entirely when parasitized by cowbirds rather than raise another bird's chicks.
/wiki/Hutton's_vireo: So similar to a ruby-crowned kinglet that even birdwatchers do double-takes, but DNA studies reveal it may actually be multiple species masquerading as one. Deliberately gleans insects from the canopy while singing its distinctive chu-wee call, named after a 19th-century US surveyor.
/wiki/Yellow-throated_vireo: Sports distinctive yellow "spectacles" around its dark eyes and forages for insects high in the treetops. This olive-backed songbird migrates thousands of miles to Central America, occasionally fueling up on tropical gumbo-limbo berries along the way.
/wiki/Cassin's_vireo: Sings its distinctive question-and-answer phrases persistently from the canopy, pausing exactly 2 seconds between each musical interrogation. Once grouped with two lookalike species under the name "solitary vireo," this patient forager methodically hunts insects while sporting bold white spectacles.
/wiki/Blue-headed_vireo: Once lumped with two other species into the "Solitary Vireo," DNA evidence in 1997 revealed it was distinct all along. This blue-crowned insectivore defends territories up to 16 acres and constantly chirps to its mate while foraging, maintaining an unusually vocal partnership throughout the breeding season.
/wiki/Plumbeous_vireo: This persistent vocalist delivers alternating high and low phrases every two seconds, creating an enchanting question-and-answer rhythm throughout pine forests. Once grouped with two look-alike relatives under the name "solitary vireo," it has since earned its own species status. Crafts delicate cup nests from bark strips and down, tucked securely in the fork of a twig.
/wiki/Philadelphia_vireo: Despite its name, this yellow-bellied songbird rarely visits Philadelphia except during migration. A master of mimicry, its song is nearly identical to the red-eyed vireo but with slightly longer pauses between phrases. It hovers acrobatically to pluck insects mid-flight before gorging on berries to fuel its journey to Central America.
/wiki/Warbling_vireo: This cheerful warbler hops along branches hunting insects and sometimes sings while sitting on its own nest during incubation. Eastern and western populations have evolved subtle differences in their songs where their ranges meet in Alberta, possibly signaling the early stages of splitting into separate species.
/wiki/Red-eyed_vireo: Holds the world record for most songs in a single day among all birds—over 20,000 vocal performances in endless question-and-answer rhythm from high in the treetops. This tireless singer has a repertoire of up to 73 different song types and spaces them just under a second apart for hours on end.
/wiki/Yellow-green_vireo: So similar to its red-eyed cousin that even experts struggle to tell them apart in hand, this yellow-washed songbird migrates thousands of miles from Central America to the Amazon basin each year. Builds its cup nest as low as 1.5 meters off the ground, feeding on caterpillars and beetles gleaned from tree foliage with surgical precision.
/wiki/Black-whiskered_vireo: Named for the distinctive black streak along its neck, this tropical songster delivers a sharp three-syllable "whip, Tom Kelly" call from the treetops. Gleans insects from foliage with surgical precision, sometimes hovering mid-air like a tiny helicopter while hunting.
/wiki/Yucatan_vireo: A dull-plumaged cousin of the red-eyed vireo that made headlines with a single 1984 appearance in Texas—the only U.S. record ever documented. This tropical wanderer typically sticks to far-flung Caribbean islands and a narrow strip of Central American coastline, making it one of the rarest birds to grace American soil.
/wiki/Kauai_elepaio: This gray-headed flycatcher crashed from 40,000 birds to just 20,000 in the 1990s, but has recently begun a hopeful recovery with populations rebounding 13% on the Alakai plateau. The most distinct of the Hawaiian elepaios, young birds sport rusty-red plumage that transforms to elegant gray and white as they mature.
/wiki/Oahu_elepaio: This rust-colored flycatcher survives in just 18 square miles of mountain forest, battling avian malaria and rat predation that threaten its eggs and nestlings. Where rats are controlled, survival rates jump dramatically, but some valleys now contain only a single individual of this isolated island species.
/wiki/Hawaii_elepaio: Originally described from a specimen collected during Captain Cook's fatal third voyage in 1779, this tiny flycatcher was once considered the same species as its cousins on Kauai and Oahu. Its genus name literally means "gaping for mosquitos," a perfect description of its hunting style as it snatches insects from the air.
/wiki/Fiji_shrikebill: Native to the South Pacific islands of Fiji, Tonga, and American Samoa, this small forest monarch flycatcher has diversified into twelve distinct subspecies across its island range. Despite its fearsome 'shrikebill' name, it's a harmless insect-eater that flits through tropical canopies far from American shores.
/wiki/Tinian_monarch: Once confined to a single island, conservationists successfully introduced this flycatcher to a second island where it now thrives. With a population rebounding from endangered status to over 38,000 individuals, it represents a rare conservation success story in the Pacific.
/wiki/Guam_flycatcher: This secretive island flycatcher vanished entirely by 1983, wiped out by the accidentally introduced brown tree snake that devastated Guam's native bird populations. Its wide bill sprouted long whisker-like bristles that acted like motion sensors, helping it pinpoint flying insects in dense forest shadows.
/wiki/Brown_shrike: Known as a "butcher bird" for its grisly habit of impaling prey on thorns to create a larder of skewered insects, lizards, and small birds. This Asian migrant shows remarkable loyalty to its wintering grounds, returning to the exact same territory year after year. Sings with its beak completely closed, only visible through throat pulsations while bobbing its tail.
/wiki/Red-backed_shrike: This carnivorous songbird earned the nickname 'butcher bird' by impaling its prey—insects, rodents, and even small birds—on thorns and barbed wire to create a gruesome larder. Once common across Britain, it vanished almost entirely by 1989, with only sporadic breeding attempts since then.
/wiki/Loggerhead_shrike: Nicknamed the 'butcherbird,' this songbird hunts like a raptor but lacks strong talons, so it impales prey on thorns and barbed wire to tear them apart. Despite weighing just 2 ounces, it kills animals larger than itself by spearing their necks with whiplash force. Its macabre larders of skewered victims can include venomous snakes, small mammals, and other birds.
/wiki/Northern_shrike: Known as the 'butcherbird,' this songbird with a raptor's beak impales its prey—mice, lizards, and other birds—on thorns and spikes like a macabre pantry. Despite having no talons, it lures victims by mimicking their calls, then dispatches them with its hooked bill.
/wiki/Canada_jay: Survives brutal winters by caching food in tree bark year-round, using the antibacterial properties of boreal conifers as a natural refrigerator. Known as the "camp robber" for its fearless approach to humans, this corvid lives on permanent territories with helper juveniles from the previous year. Despite its friendly reputation, southern populations face threats from climate change disrupting their cold-storage food system.
/wiki/Brown_jay: This indiscriminate feeder raids nests only when desperate, preferring insects, lizards, and fruit when available. Northern and southern populations look so different they seem like separate species, with an intergrade zone in Veracruz where the two forms meet. Young helpers from previous broods return to assist their parents, but must pass food to the adults rather than feeding chicks directly.
/wiki/Green_jay: A remarkably vocal corvid with an alarm-bell call and dozens of other unusual notes in its repertoire. Uses sticks as tools to pry insects from tree bark and caches acorns for later like a feathered squirrel. Its bright plumage shifts from yellow-breasted in the south to pale green in Texas populations.
/wiki/Pinyon_jay: Lives in massive flocks of 250+ birds with dedicated sentries watching for threats while others feast on pinyon pine seeds. Forms lifelong pair bonds and can cache thousands of seeds in hidden spots across miles of territory, accidentally planting forests in the process. Its survival is so intertwined with pinyon pines that it times breeding to seed crop abundance, sometimes nesting as early as January in anticipation of future harvests.
/wiki/Steller's_jay: A master mimic that perfectly imitates the calls of hawks and other predators to clear out feeding areas for itself. This crested jay can assess different levels of danger by analyzing whether threats are seen or only heard, adjusting its alarm calls accordingly. The only crested jay west of the Rockies, it caches thousands of seeds and acorns in hidden spots for winter survival.
/wiki/Blue_jay: Its brilliant blue isn't from pigment at all—crush a feather and the color vanishes as the microscopic structures break apart. This aggressive corvid raids nests, imitates hawk calls to scare off competitors, and has been documented decapitating other birds.
/wiki/Florida_scrub-jay: The only bird species endemic to Florida, this cooperative breeder caches thousands of acorns annually, accidentally planting forests in the process. Remarkably tame and intelligent, it will take food from human hands—but early feeding disrupts breeding cycles, causing chicks to hatch before their caterpillar prey emerges.
/wiki/Island_scrub-jay: The only insular endemic landbird in continental North America, found exclusively on a single California island where it has been evolving in isolation for approximately one million years. Its stout bill morphology varies between oak and pine habitats, with individuals preferentially mating with partners who share similar bill shapes. Buries acorns in fall caches and may remember their locations months later.
/wiki/California_scrub-jay: One of the only non-primates shown to plan for the future, this corvid remembers over 200 food cache locations and their decay rates. Its brain-to-body mass ratio rivals chimpanzees, and it holds elaborate "funerals" over dead companions that can last half an hour.
/wiki/Woodhouse's_scrub-jay: One of the few non-primates that can plan for the future, this brainy corvid remembers the exact locations of over 200 food caches and even checks to make sure no one is watching before hiding its stolen acorns. Its brain-to-body mass ratio rivals that of chimpanzees and cetaceans, dwarfed only by humans.
/wiki/Mexican_jay: Operates a family daycare where teenage birds from previous years help raise their younger siblings. Hoards acorns and pine nuts in autumn like a feathered squirrel, stashing away provisions for the lean winter months. The pink bill of juveniles turns black with age, though museum specimens misleadingly show it as yellow.
/wiki/Clark's_nutcracker: Can cache up to 98,000 pine seeds per season and relocate them with pinpoint accuracy nine months later, even under a meter of snow. This remarkable spatial memory allows it to engineer entire forests—surplus seeds left buried germinate into new trees, perpetuating its own habitat for generations.
/wiki/Black-billed_magpie: Once hunted as a pest in the 1900s, this bold corvid rides on cattle's backs to pluck off ticks and follows wolves to scavenge their kills. Builds elaborate domed nests from twigs and can recognize individual humans who've disturbed its eggs, mobbing them specifically while ignoring others nearby.
/wiki/Yellow-billed_magpie: When one of their own dies, a gathering of magpies holds a funeral, calling out loudly for 10-15 minutes around the deceased. West Nile virus devastated the population between 2004-2006, killing an estimated 50% of all individuals. Males practice mate-guarding after copulation, following their partner everywhere until she lays her first egg.
/wiki/Eurasian_jackdaw: This highly intelligent corvid has been observed using tools and lives in complex social groups with a sophisticated hierarchy. Named for its supposed habit of stealing coins, it sports distinctive pale-grey eyes that start blue in juveniles. Monogamous pairs build stick nests in cavities and can execute tight aerial maneuvers with characteristic jerky wingbeats.
/wiki/Mariana_crow: Teetering on the brink of extinction with fewer than 200 individuals remaining, this glossy black crow was completely wiped out on Guam by the invasive brown tree snake. Devoted parents care for their young for up to 18 months, and juveniles may not breed until they're 3 years old—a slow reproduction rate that makes recovery nearly impossible.
/wiki/American_crow: Possesses the same brain-to-body weight ratio as humans and has been observed crafting and using tools to obtain food. This highly intelligent corvid can mimic the calls of other animals and lives in cooperative family groups of up to 15 individuals across multiple generations. Populations have dropped 45% since 1999 due to extreme susceptibility to West Nile virus, making them valuable bioindicators for tracking the disease's spread.
/wiki/White-necked_crow: Despite its name, the white neck feathers are hidden at the base and rarely visible in the field.
