Young larvae are so aggressive they'll devour their own siblings within days of hatching if not kept in darkness.
/wiki/Basking_shark: The second-largest fish on Earth can breach completely out of the water despite weighing up to 16 tons. Its cavernous mouth, nearly a meter wide, filters tons of plankton as it lazily cruises at just 2 knots. One individual tracked crossing the equator spent a month at the mouth of the Amazon River, possibly to aid reproduction.
/wiki/Bay_anchovy: The most abundant fish in Chesapeake Bay, a single female can spawn 50 times per season, releasing over 50,000 eggs total. This tiny schooling fish serves as the critical link converting zooplankton into food for striped bass, bluefish, and terns—making it the engine of the Atlantic coastal food web.
/wiki/Bearded_brotula: Armed with 12 whisker-like barbels on its face and chin, this deep-dwelling carnivore prowls sandy ocean bottoms hunting crabs and fish in near-total darkness. Can grow nearly as long as a human is tall and releases masses of gelatin-like eggs that drift through open water.
/wiki/Beaugregory: This territorial damselfish can assess the threat level of egg-stealing wrasses and adjust its defensive tactics accordingly. Males guard their nests by fanning eggs with their fins to keep them oxygenated. Juveniles sport a distinctive blue-ringed eyespot that migrates upward onto the dorsal fin as they mature.
/wiki/Belted_sandfish: A tiny predator that can be both male and female simultaneously, employing three different mating strategies depending on its size and mood. Hunts at dusk by creating powerful suction with its oversized mouth, swallowing prey whole like an underwater vacuum cleaner.
/wiki/Bermuda_blue_angelfish: Young individuals operate underwater cleaning stations, picking parasites off larger fish, while adults form lifelong monogamous pairs and can produce up to 10 million eggs per spawning season. Produces loud thumping sounds to startle predators. Frequently hybridizes with the queen angelfish in overlapping territories.
/wiki/Bermuda_chub: This globe-trotting reef fish has been spotted feeding on dolphin feces and vomit, a bizarre dietary shift from its usual algae meals. Juveniles hitchhike across oceans by sheltering in floating rafts of Sargassum seaweed. Some individuals inexplicably turn bright yellow with black blotches instead of their normal bronze-green coloration.
/wiki/Bicolor_damselfish: Unlike its algae-grazing cousins, this split-toned reef dweller breaks the family mold by feeding exclusively on plankton. Forms loose gangs of up to twenty individuals that aggressively defend rocky territories riddled with hiding spots.
/wiki/Bicolour_parrotfish: Changes sex not once but twice during its lifetime, transforming from white juvenile to dark brown female to brilliantly colored green-and-pink male. Males fiercely guard their territories on Red Sea reefs, where this algae-grazer can reach nearly two feet in length.
/wiki/Bigeye_sand_tiger: One of the world's rarest sharks, so elusive that scientists once thought it might just be a variant of another species. Its massive orange eyes and dark coloration reveal a life spent hunting in the perpetual twilight of the ocean's mesopelagic zone. Embryos cannibalize unfertilized eggs in the womb to fuel their growth.
/wiki/Bigeye_scad: A nocturnal schooling fish with enormous eyes that hunts tiny prey under cover of darkness. Supports a massive 200,000-tonne global fishery annually, prized as both food and bait across tropical seas.
/wiki/Bigeye_thresher: Nearly half its body length is a whip-like tail used to stun prey with devastating strikes. Equipped with enormous upward-facing eyes the size of softballs, it migrates vertically each day—diving to 2,000+ feet during daylight and rising to surface waters at night to hunt. Possesses a special vascular heat-exchange system to protect its brain from temperature shock during these extreme depth changes.
/wiki/Bigeye_tuna: This deep-diving predator can plunge 500 meters into frigid, oxygen-poor waters that would suffocate most fish, thanks to specialized blood and heat exchangers that warm its body 20°C above the surrounding ocean. It tracks the thermocline across entire ocean basins, following prey that migrate between surface and depths with the rhythm of day and night.
/wiki/Bignose_shark: A deepwater wanderer that migrates thousands of miles between summer and winter grounds, swimming near the ocean floor at depths up to 1,410 feet. Rises toward the surface at night in vertical migrations, hunting bony fish and squid with its distinctive tall triangular teeth. Despite reaching 9 feet and 370 pounds, it lives too deep to pose much threat to humans.
/wiki/Black_acara: An accidental invader from Venezuela that spawns year-round in Florida's warm waters, laying about 1,000 eggs per clutch while both parents fiercely guard their young. This scrappy omnivore thrives in oxygen-poor roadside ditches that few other fish can tolerate, outcompeting native sunfish for prime spawning spots.
/wiki/Black_arowana: Nicknamed "water monkey" for its spectacular leaps out of the water to snatch prey from overhanging branches, including small bats and even monkeys. Males carry up to 210 eggs in their mouths until the young reach nearly 3 inches long. Its draw-bridge-like mouth is perfectly designed to gulp down anything floating on the surface.
/wiki/Black_carp: Armed with mill-like pharyngeal teeth that crush snails and mussels like a hydraulic press, this invasive giant can reach 6 feet long and 240 pounds. Accidentally introduced in the 1970s, it now threatens dozens of critically endangered native mollusks across the vast Mississippi basin—a watershed covering over a million square miles.
/wiki/Black_drum: Armed with powerful jaws that can crush two dozen oysters a day, this bottom-dwelling drummer produces mating calls between 100-500 Hz. A single school can devastate a commercial oyster bed in hours, and the largest specimens can live up to 60 years and weigh over 100 pounds.
/wiki/Black_durgon: This blimp-shaped fish has developed an unusual feeding strategy: positioning itself beneath spinner dolphins to feast on their feces and vomit. Despite appearing completely black from a distance, closer inspection reveals mottled blue-green coloration with the ability to change colors based on surroundings.
/wiki/Black_grouper: A master of transformation, this massive reef predator starts life as a female and changes into a male around age 15, growing up to 220 pounds. Forms seasonal feeding frenzies along continental shelves, timing their hunts to coincide with the spawning aggregations of prey fish like grunts and snappers.
/wiki/Black_jack_(fish): This jet-black predator of the deep prefers oceanic islands over continental shores, prowling reefs at depths up to 354 meters. Schools coordinate their movements by detecting chemical signals released from coral reefs. Known to cause ciguatera poisoning despite being prized as a gamefish around tropical islands.
/wiki/Black_margate: A nocturnal hunter with fleshy lips and conical teeth, this grunt feasts on spiny sea urchins that most fish avoid. Juveniles sport racing stripes and a tail spot that vanish with age, replaced by a silvery body split between dark and light halves. Large specimens can cause ciguatera poisoning, making this reef dweller more dangerous on the dinner plate than in the water.
/wiki/Black_marlin: One of the largest bony fish in the world, capable of dragging boats for miles when hooked. Its rigid pectoral fins distinguish it from all other marlins—they lock outward and can't fold flat against the body. Despite popular myths of extreme speed, studies show its burst speed tops out around 22 mph, far slower than legend suggests.
/wiki/Black_seabass: A shape-shifting hermaphrodite that begins life as female and transforms into a brilliant blue-green male when the spawning group needs more males. Rests vertically on the seafloor in head-up or head-down positions, raising its spiny dorsal fin as a warning signal to rivals.
/wiki/Black_sharkminnow: This aggressive territorial giant of Southeast Asian rivers can grow to three feet long and weighs up to 15 pounds, making it a poor choice for home aquariums despite its popularity in the fish trade. Sometimes called the black shark, it patrols the Mekong and Chao Phraya basins with fierce authority.
/wiki/Blackbar_soldierfish: This nocturnal reef-dweller hunts plankton and shrimp under cover of darkness, sporting a striking crimson body with a distinctive black bar behind its head. Bizarrely, it's sometimes spotted swimming completely upside-down through the depths.
/wiki/Blackchin_tilapia: An invasive African cichlid that tolerates pure seawater and can comprise 90% of fish biomass in invaded waters, breeding so rapidly that a single die-off killed 20,000 individuals—less than 1% of one reservoir's population. A paternal mouthbrooder where males carry eggs in their mouths, though females reverse roles in some populations.
/wiki/Black-ear_wrasse: Every individual starts life as a female, but some transform into males around 8cm in length. Unlike most wrasses where males form harems, males of this species gather in flashy leks to competitively display for females. The only member of its genus whose larvae develop specialized internal chromatophores.
/wiki/Blackedge_moray_eel: Lurking in reef crevices with distinctive black-edged fins, this serpentine predator has been patrolling Caribbean and Gulf waters since before the Civil War was documented. Its powerful jaws can deliver a nasty bite if provoked, but it prefers to stay hidden during daylight hunts.
/wiki/Blackfin_snapper: Lurks in the deep at 200-300 feet with a telltale black comma marking its pectoral fins, hunting smaller fish near the seafloor. Despite being prized at markets, this red snapper has earned a dangerous reputation for sometimes carrying ciguatera toxin. Juveniles sport a vivid yellow patch that fades as they mature and move from shallow reefs to deeper continental waters.
/wiki/Blackfin_tuna: The smallest tuna species, maxing out at just 21 kg, yet sushi-grade and prized by sport fishermen. Spawns in the nutrient-rich Gulf of Mexico, where Mississippi River outflow fuels the ravenous appetites of its fast-growing larvae. Distinguished by its brownish dorsal finlets and remarkably few gill rakers—just 20-23 compared to 30+ in other tunas.
/wiki/Blacknose_shark: Fast enough to snatch food from larger Caribbean reef sharks, this small predator performs an elaborate threat display by hunching its back and gaping its jaws. Despite its speed and aggressive posture, it has never attacked a human and typically measures just over 4 feet long.
/wiki/Blacktail_moray_eel: A secretive ambush predator that lurks in reef crevices with only its head exposed, waiting to strike at passing prey with powerful jaws. Its distinctive black-tipped tail helps distinguish it from the dozens of other moray species prowling Atlantic waters.
/wiki/Blacktail_redhorse: Sports a distinctive black stripe on its red tail fin and spawns using a unique aggregation technique where multiple males swarm a single female. Females produce massive clutches of up to 17,000 eggs that hatch in just over a week. During winter, mature individuals migrate downstream into deeper water to wait out the cold.
/wiki/Blacktip_shark: This energetic hunter makes spectacular spinning leaps out of the water while corkscrewing through schools of fish at speeds exceeding 20 feet per second. In the absence of males, females can reproduce asexually. Young sharks return to the exact nurseries where they were born to give birth themselves.
/wiki/Blue_chromis: Males of this vibrant reef dweller breed with multiple females, then stand guard over the eggs until they hatch into planktonic larvae. Despite making up nearly half the aquarium trade alongside other damselfish, it remains abundant across 2.5 million square kilometers of tropical waters. Now faces an unexpected threat from invasive lionfish rapidly expanding through its Caribbean home.
/wiki/Blue_hamlet: A gender-bending reef predator that can switch between male and female roles during spawning. Disguises itself as the harmless blue chromis—complete with an elongated body and forked tail—possibly to sneak close enough to devour chromis babies. This iridescent blue trickster proves that on the reef, looking friendly doesn't mean you are.
/wiki/Atlantic_blue_marlin: Females grow four times larger than males, reaching over 1,800 pounds and 16 feet in length. Uses its massive bill like a club to stun entire schools of fish before circling back to feast. A tagged individual once traveled over 9,000 miles from Delaware to Mauritius in the Indian Ocean.
/wiki/Blue_parrotfish: A living sand factory that grinds ingested coral rocks with specialized throat teeth, literally pooping out the white sand beaches of the Caribbean. This uniformly blue reef grazer spends 80% of its life hunting for algae in groups of up to 500, sporting a distinctive beak that scrapes organisms off rocks. The only parrotfish species to maintain brilliant blue coloring into adulthood.
/wiki/Blue_runner: A schooling predator that's irresistibly drawn to any large floating object, from oil platforms to sargassum mats. Completely switches its diet based on location—devouring fish and crustaceans near shore but feeding almost exclusively on tiny zooplankton in the open ocean. Thousands of tonnes are caught annually, yet it's considered a mediocre table fish and often ends up as bait itself.
/wiki/Blue_shark: Female blue sharks can birth litters of over 100 pups and have evolved skin three times thicker than males to withstand the violent biting of courtship rituals. These elegant predators work together in coordinated packs to herd prey, migrating thousands of miles between New England and South America in clockwise patterns following ocean currents.
/wiki/Blue_striped_grunt: Named for the grunting sounds it produces with pharyngeal teeth, this reef dweller has a vivid red mouth and spends its days resting in rocky areas before venturing out to hunt at night. Young fish hide in turtle grass until they develop the distinctive blue racing stripes that give adults their name.
/wiki/Blue_surgeonfish: Armed with a razor-sharp "surgeon's scalpel" spine at the base of its tail, this territorial herbivore defends its algae patch aggressively. The intensity of its brilliant blue coloration serves as a health indicator, fading when the fish is unwell.
/wiki/Blue_tilapia: This invasive mouthbrooder carries up to 1,600 eggs at once and thrives in extreme conditions—from freshwater to waters saltier than the ocean. Originally imported from Israel to control aquatic weeds, it now dominates ecosystems from the Everglades to Nevada, outcompeting native fish and decimating mussel populations.
/wiki/Blueback_herring: This silver wanderer migrates over 1,200 miles through ocean depths, spawning in swift rivers before racing back to sea. Often confused with its cousin the alewife, it's distinguished by a distinctive black abdominal lining and deep blue-green back. A female can release up to 103,000 eggs that stick to stream bottoms like aquatic confetti.
/wiki/Bluefish: Infamous for feeding frenzies so violent they churn shallow water like a washing machine, continuing to shred schools of fish even after gorging themselves full. These aggressive predators have been known to bite swimmers and are cannibalistic enough to devour their own young. Can live up to 9 years but goes rancid so quickly after death that it's rarely found far from its fisheries.
/wiki/Bluehead_wrasse: This reef janitor can change both sex and color in just 8 days, with females transforming into aggressive territorial males when dominant males disappear. Small males pack oversized testes to compete in "spawning rushes" with up to 50 rivals, while larger males guard harems and turn metallic green when chasing competitors.
/wiki/Bluelip_parrotfish: This seagrass specialist starts life as a female and later transforms into a male—a shape-shifting strategy that helps maximize reproductive success. Its vibrant blue lips give away its identity as it grazes peacefully through underwater meadows.
/wiki/Bluespotted_cornetfish: This impossibly slender reef predator invaded the entire Mediterranean Sea from a single colonization event in just 20 years, exploding across thousands of miles. Its tubular snout works like a vacuum to slurp up juvenile fish from seagrass beds, devastating native populations before they reach adulthood.
/wiki/Bluespotted_ribbontail_ray: This striking ray with electric blue spots hunts at night in groups, excavating sand pits to trap prey beneath its body before maneuvering meals into its mouth. When threatened, it flees in high-speed zigzag patterns and packs venomous tail spines capable of inflicting excruciating wounds. Despite being the most popular stingray in the aquarium trade, most captive specimens mysteriously refuse to feed and die.
/wiki/Bluntnose_sixgill_shark: A living fossil with six gill slits instead of the usual five, this deep-sea predator has relatives dating back 200 million years. Performs nightly vertical migrations from depths of 2,000+ feet to hunt near the surface, then descends before dawn to conserve energy. Can grow to 26 feet and uses saw-like teeth to tear apart prey ranging from squid to seals.
/wiki/Bluntnose_stingray: Spends most of the day buried in sand, then emerges at night to hunt crustaceans and worms. Females pause embryo development for 10 months after mating, waiting until spring when food is plentiful before their young complete development in just 10 weeks. That venomous tail spine can ruin a beachgoer's day if stepped on in shallow water.
/wiki/Bonefish: Known as the "grey ghost" for its wariness and silver shimmer, this prized gamefish feeds on shallow flats with incoming tides, sometimes following stingrays to snatch prey they disturb from the sand. Despite weighing up to 14 pounds, it's so skittish that catching one requires extraordinary stealth and skill.
/wiki/Bonnethead: The only known omnivorous shark, it digests seagrass with 50% efficiency using cellulose-degrading enzymes in its hindgut. Hunts by sweeping its spade-shaped head like a metal detector, sensing electromagnetic disturbances from crabs buried in sediment. One captive female reproduced via parthenogenesis, creating a genetically identical pup without mating.
/wiki/Bridled_burrfish: When threatened, this spiny fish inflates like a balloon by gulping water or air, transforming into a near-impenetrable sphere bristling with fixed spines. Its bizarre tentacles above the eyes and polka-dot pattern make it look more like an alien creature than a fish, perfectly camouflaged among tropical reefs.
/wiki/Brook_silverside: Lives fast and dies young—this translucent fish rockets through its entire lifecycle in just one year, growing up to a millimeter per day to reach breeding age by its first summer. A highly specialized feeder with cladocerans making up 80% of its diet, it thrives only in crystal-clear waters and vanishes when turbidity rises.
/wiki/Brown_garden_eel: Lives its entire adult life rooted in sandy seafloors within colonies, extending from burrows like periscopes to snatch passing plankton. The larval stage drifts in ocean currents for up to 8 months before finally settling down to join a garden of motionless hunters.
/wiki/Brown_hoplo: This armored catfish builds elaborate bubble nests in oxygen-poor swamps and breathes through its intestines when gills aren't enough. Males guard fortress-like foam domes containing up to 20,000 eggs, attacking intruders with razor-sharp pectoral spines. Females drink sperm directly from males, with fertilization occurring as it passes through their digestive tract.
/wiki/Bull_shark: One of the few sharks that can thrive in both saltwater and freshwater, swimming up the Mississippi River as far as Illinois—over 700 miles from the ocean. Possesses the highest bite force of any cartilaginous fish and is responsible for more nearshore attacks than any other species. Has even been spotted swimming through flooded city streets in Australia.
/wiki/Bullet_mackerel: This sleek predator streaks through tropical seas with distinctive zig-zag markings along its back, hunting down small fish and squid. Despite its fierce name and torpedo-shaped body, it's one of the smaller tuna species, maxing out at just 20 inches long.
/wiki/Bullnose_ray: Glides through coastal shallows with wing-like fins, crushing hermit crabs and mollusks with powerful grinding plates. Often mistaken for its southern cousin, this eagle ray gives birth to just six pups per litter, making population recovery a slow process.
/wiki/Southern_eagle_ray: This seasonal migrant returns to the same estuary or bay each spring and summer to give birth, with young staying in nursery waters for over a year before venturing to the open ocean. Feeds on invertebrates along the seafloor at depths up to 200 meters, though it prefers shallow waters with soft, muddy bottoms. Often confused with its relative the bullnose ray, but ventures into much deeper waters than its look-alike cousin.
/wiki/Bullseye_snakehead: A fast-growing air-breathing fish that can survive out of water, this invasive predator from South Asia fetches premium prices for its boneless, delicious flesh. What was once considered a single species is actually a complex of multiple distinct lineages spanning from India to Southeast Asia.
/wiki/Caesar_grunt: A nocturnal reef dweller that earned its "coal-like" Spanish name from its distinctive dark fins and black tail spot. Schools of these social fish hunt the seafloor at night for crabs, starfish, and snails, their orange-mouthed jaws leaving no doubt about their identity.
/wiki/Caribbean_chestnut_moray: The smallest member of its genus, this pint-sized predator maxes out at just over a foot long. It weaves through coral and rocky reefs in shallow tropical waters, proving that morays don't need to be massive to be mighty.
/wiki/Caribbean_ocellated_moray: Lurking in Caribbean coral crevices with its serpentine body, this spotted predator has earned at least eight different common names from confused sailors and fishermen. Its saw-like teeth and muscular bite help it grip slippery prey in the reef's tight spaces.
/wiki/Caribbean_reef_shark: This apex predator has been documented 'sleeping' motionless in underwater caves—a bizarre behavior for an active-swimming shark that may produce a narcotic-like effect. Can evert its entire stomach to cleanse parasites and debris, and performs an aggressive threat display by jerking through the water while dropping its pectoral fins.
/wiki/Caribbean_sharpnose-puffer: Can inflate to three times its normal size by gulping water into an expandable stomach, making it nearly impossible to swallow. Armed with tetrodotoxin so deadly it has killed sea turtles that ate it, yet crawls through the water so slowly it relies entirely on being poisonous to survive. Males defend harems of up to six females, violently attacking intruders in their territory.
/wiki/Cero_(fish): Distinguished from its relatives by a bold longitudinal racing stripe alongside its spotted pattern, this sleek predator patrols tropical waters from Cape Cod to Brazil. Can reach weights of 10 pounds or more, with rare giants exceeding 30 pounds cruising the warm Atlantic currents.
/wiki/Chain_dogfish: This biofluorescent deep-sea dweller glows in patterns visible only to other sharks, possibly for secret communication in the darkness. Females can store sperm for over two years after mating, laying pairs of eggs with coiled tendrils that snag onto rocks. Spends days motionless on the seafloor camouflaged against rubble, then springs to life at night to hunt.
/wiki/Chain_moray: This nocturnal hunter sports specialized blunt teeth designed to crush crab shells like a nutcracker. Can survive up to half an hour out of water while hunting in tide pools, striking at prey with lightning speed even when partially beached.
/wiki/Chalk_bass: A master of disguise that changes its color and pattern to match its surroundings. This synchronous hermaphrodite possesses both male and female organs simultaneously, making every individual a potential mate in its hierarchical social groups.
/wiki/Checkered_puffer: Armed with four fused teeth forming a powerful beak that can crack open mollusks and crustaceans, this fish inflates like a balloon when threatened by gulping water or air. Its sandpapery skin and distinctive checkered pattern help distinguish it from three other puffer cousins in Florida waters.
/wiki/Cherubfish: This tiny deep blue angelfish with an orange face lives in harems of up to 10 individuals, with a single male ruling over his females. Despite its popularity in aquariums, it typically dwells well below recreational diving depths at 30+ meters, retreating into rocky cavities when threatened.
/wiki/Clearnose_skate: Named for the translucent windows on either side of its snout, this bottom-dwelling cartilaginous fish "walks" along the seafloor using modified pelvic fins in a behavior called punting. Its embryos demonstrate a remarkable freeze response when detecting electric fields, stopping all movement to hide from predators while still encased in their leathery egg pouches.
/wiki/Clown_featherback: This nocturnal air-breather can survive in oxygen-poor waters and grows up to three feet long, quickly outgrowing home aquariums. Armed with a toothed mouth and spots ringed in white, it uses its distinctive knife-like body and long anal fin to glide gracefully forward and backward through the water.
/wiki/Coastal_shiner: A silvery minnow that traces the Atlantic and Gulf coasts through countless river systems, thriving where fresh water meets the salt. Its range follows the warm southeastern waterways like a liquid highway from the Carolinas to the Mississippi delta.
/wiki/Cobia: This curious fish impersonates a shark by holding its pectoral fins horizontally and follows larger ocean predators like manta rays to scavenge their leftovers. Females can spawn up to 30 times in a single season, releasing millions of tiny eggs into ocean currents. Despite reaching 172 pounds, it lacks a swim bladder entirely.
/wiki/Collared_eel: Lives its entire life hidden inside tubular sponges on coral reefs, rarely venturing out. When hit with blue or UV light, this tiny eel glows bright orange—a biofluorescent trick that may help it communicate with others or hide from predators in the colorful reef environment.
/wiki/Colon_goby: This tiny reef-dweller measures barely two inches long, making it one of the smallest fish patrolling Caribbean waters. Despite its diminutive size, it ranges across thousands of miles from Florida to Brazil, carving out a niche in the competitive world of coral reefs.
/wiki/Common_clownfish: Lives in a strict social hierarchy where males can transform into females, and the entire group depends on a symbiotic bond with venomous sea anemones whose stings they've evolved to resist. Fathers obsessively tend their eggs for up to eight days, fanning them constantly and eating any that become infected. Forms "queues" where fish wait their turn to climb the social ladder simply by outliving more dominant members above them.
/wiki/Common_lionfish: An invasive Indo-Pacific predator armed with venomous spines that can cause extreme pain, paralysis, and breathing difficulties in humans. First spotted in US waters in the 1990s, it now dominates Caribbean reefs with few natural predators—though moray eels have developed resistance to its toxic defenses.
/wiki/Common_rudd: An invasive appetite on fins that can devour 40% of its body weight in aquatic plants daily, then discharge 80% as waste that floods waterways with nutrients. Illegally spread across continents, this European transplant lays up to 200,000 eggs at a time and readily hybridizes with native species, threatening indigenous ecosystems.
/wiki/Common_thresher: Wields its enormous tail—half its total body length—like a whip to stun entire schools of fish with incapacitating blows. Despite reaching 20 feet and over 1,000 pounds, it's surprisingly harmless to humans due to tiny teeth and a timid nature. Can maintain body temperatures warmer than surrounding water and has been seen leaping completely out of the ocean.
/wiki/Convict_cichlid: Named for its prison-stripe pattern, this devoted parent can breed as young as 16 weeks old and will fan its eggs continuously day and night—using smell to locate them in total darkness. Unusually for fish, females are more colorful than males and form monogamous bonds, with both parents fiercely guarding offspring for up to six weeks.
/wiki/Copper_shark: This bronze predator doesn't reach sexual maturity until nearly 20 years old, making it painfully vulnerable to overfishing. Follows South Africa's epic sardine runs in massive hunting packs, using sheer numbers to corral millions of fish. Despite growing to 11 feet long, it's only responsible for 15 recorded non-fatal attacks on humans.
/wiki/Cownose_ray: Often mistaken for sharks when their fins break the surface, these migratory rays crush clams with jaws as hard as cement and travel in massive schools. Despite being scapegoated for destroying oyster beds, they're actually vulnerable to overfishing due to late maturity and 11-12 month pregnancies that produce just one pup.
/wiki/Creole_wrasse: This violet-purple fish changes sex when the dominant male dies, with the largest female transforming to take his place. Males gather at underwater leks to dance and display for approaching females, making this one of the ocean's most elaborate courtship rituals.
/wiki/Crested_goby: Most are born female, but some transform into males during their lifetime—though males born male stay that way forever. This adaptable fish thrives equally in fresh or saltwater, hiding among mangrove roots while munching mostly on algae. Can breed any time of year, securing eggs to rocky seabeds where currents can't sweep them away.
/wiki/Crevalle_Jack: A powerful predator growing up to 4 feet long and 70 pounds, this aggressive hunter is both a prized gamefish and an important commercial catch throughout the Atlantic. Young fish swept north by currents face mass die-offs if they fail to migrate back before winter temperatures drop below their tolerance. The first jack species ever scientifically named, it literally translates to "horse mackerel" in Latin.
/wiki/Croaking_gourami: This Southeast Asian import produces audible croaking sounds using its pectoral fins during territorial disputes that can last for hours. Males build bubble nests from air and mucous to house their eggs, tenderly spitting each one into place. Possesses a specialized labyrinth organ that allows it to breathe atmospheric air directly from the surface.
/wiki/Cuban_gar: A living fossil that can breathe air when water oxygen runs low and tolerates toxic ammonia levels that would kill most fish. Spawns in massive hunting parties of 20 individuals, though normally a solitary predator. Its flesh is edible, but its eggs are deadly poisonous to humans.
/wiki/Cuban_dogfish: A slim gray shark harvested commercially not for its meat, but for the oil and vitamins packed into its liver. Hosts unusually enormous parasitic isopods in its mouth and gills that dwarf those found on other marine fish.
/wiki/Cubbyu: Sports dramatic black and white racing stripes along its entire body, earning it the unusual nickname "donkeyfish." Its tall, pointed dorsal fin gives it a distinctive silhouette among Caribbean reef fish, looking almost like a mohawk cutting through the water.
/wiki/Cubera_snapper: The largest snapper species, capable of living 55 years and reaching 126 pounds with canine teeth strong enough to crunch through lobsters and crabs. Gathers in spawning aggregations of up to 10,000 fish during summer full moons, a spectacle so predictable it made them vulnerable to overfishing. Larger individuals can accumulate ciguatera toxins that cause poisoning in humans, making them dangerous to eat in some regions.
/wiki/Diamond_blenny: This tiny jewel of the reef lives at depths up to 230 feet, patrolling coral formations in the warm Caribbean waters. Named for its sparkling appearance, it's one of dozens of blenny species that dart among reef crevices with nervous energy.
/wiki/Diamond_killifish: Thrives in hypersaline flats where few other fish can survive, tolerating salt concentrations that would be lethal to most freshwater species. Recent DNA analysis revealed this tiny marsh dweller actually belongs to a completely different genus than scientists thought for decades.
/wiki/Doctorfish: This tiny Middle Eastern fish has been turned into a living pedicure tool at spas worldwide, where it nibbles dead skin off human feet. Despite claims of therapeutic benefits for psoriasis, the practice is banned in many US states because the fish can't be sanitized between customers like traditional spa tools.
/wiki/Doctorfish_tang: Armed with razor-sharp "scalpels" on either side of its tail, this surgeon of the sea wields its blades in territorial fights and against predators. Its gizzard-like organ grinds food with swallowed sand particles, while its eggs hatch within just 24 hours into translucent, diamond-shaped larvae.
/wiki/Dog_snapper: Named for its massive canine teeth that remain visible even when its mouth is closed, this nocturnal predator hunts fish and invertebrates around coral reefs. Can grow to over 4 feet long and weigh 63 pounds, but larger specimens may carry dangerous ciguatoxin that makes them unsafe to eat.
/wiki/Dusky_pipefish: In a rare role reversal, males carry fertilized eggs in a brood pouch and nourish embryos through a placenta-like connection while competing to attract multiple female mates. Larger males win the reproductive lottery, able to carry more eggs and attract more partners. Warmer waters accelerate the breeding race, with males filling their pouches faster than females can keep up.
/wiki/Dusky_shark: Tied for the longest pregnancy in the animal kingdom at up to 24 months, females then rest a full year before breeding again in a grueling three-year cycle. This apex predator migrates thousands of kilometers seasonally and doesn't reach adulthood until around 20 years of age, making it extremely vulnerable to overfishing. Can dive to 400 meters and reaches over 4 meters in length, hunting everything from fish to sea turtles to garbage.
/wiki/Dwarf_frogfish: The smallest frogfish in the Western Atlantic at just 2.5 inches, this master of disguise lurks motionless on reefs waiting to ambush prey. Relatively uncommon and found at depths up to 240 feet, it's a rare treat for divers lucky enough to spot one.
/wiki/Dwarf_rainbowfish: This iridescent blue jumper stages elaborate morning battles where males circle and nip each other while flashing their fins at maximum brilliance. Females respond by spawning continuously for days, scattering eggs that hatch within a week. Despite barely reaching 2 inches, their explosive energy demands surprisingly spacious swimming room.
/wiki/Eastern_mosquitofish: Introduced worldwide to control mosquitoes, this aggressive livebearing fish has instead become an ecological nightmare, driving native fish and frogs to extinction while thriving in water toxic enough to kill most other species. Females form defensive shoals to escape relentless male harassment that can cut their foraging efficiency in half.
/wiki/Eastern_mudminnow: A remarkably hardy bottom-feeder that thrives in acidic waters (pH 3.5) that would kill most fish, and has survived an entire night out of water. Males court females with body quivers and elaborate fin displays before building nests under rocks or in sandy depressions.
/wiki/Emperor_angelfish: Undergoes a dramatic transformation from youth to adulthood, shifting from concentric blue and white circles to bold horizontal yellow and blue stripes. Forms lifelong pairs and moonlights as a cleaner fish, picking parasites off larger species. When startled, produces an audible knocking sound to warn intruders.
/wiki/Eyed_flounder: A master of disguise that can perfectly match its sandy background in just 2-8 seconds. This flatfish spends its life lying on its right side, with both eyes migrated to the left side of its head. Males defend harems of up to six females, synchronizing spawning at sunset in carefully choreographed underwater dances.
/wiki/Finetooth_shark: An energetic predator that forms large schools in the surf zone, hunting almost exclusively Atlantic menhaden which it swallows whole after removing the head. Males produce bizarre spermatozeugmas—congealed spongy masses of semen—inside females during mating, a structure whose purpose remains unknown. Despite thrashing violently when caught, this needle-toothed shark has never attacked a human unprovoked.
/wiki/Firemouth_cichlid: Males flash their brilliant red throats like warning lights, flaring their gills wide to intimidate rivals during territorial disputes. Devoted parents form lifelong pairs and carefully shepherd their young through dangerous waters, with fathers defending the territory while mothers tend the fry. Their protruding jaws can extend 6% of their body length, though this limits them to catching only slower prey.
/wiki/Flagfish: Holds the Guinness World Record for laying the fewest eggs of any fish species—just 20 over several days. Males display their patriotic red, white, and blue-striped pattern while performing elaborate backflips during courtship. One of the few fish that actively consumes hair algae, making it a prized natural cleaner in aquariums.
/wiki/Flamefish: A nocturnal hunter that lurks in reef shadows by day, emerging only after dark to feed. Its brilliant red-orange coloration fades in captivity unless sustained with special vitamins. Can be viewed with red light without disturbing its nighttime activities.
/wiki/Flat_needlefish: Caught at night using artificial lights, this elongated predator has bizarre green-colored flesh that keeps it off dinner plates. Its jaws are so brittle they frequently break off, forcing scientists to measure body length without including the head.
/wiki/Florida_bass: A taxonomic identity crisis on fins—recent DNA evidence suggests this fish is actually the "true" largemouth bass, forcing scientists to swap names that have been used for 200 years. When introduced outside its range, its genes spread so rapidly through native populations that pure largemouth bass populations can vanish within generations.
/wiki/Florida_gar: An ancient ambush predator that breathes air through its swim bladder and delivers lightning-fast strikes lasting only 25-40 milliseconds. During droughts, it burrows into marsh sediments and enters aestivation—a summer hibernation that lets it survive extreme heat. Its eggs are highly toxic to humans and birds alike.
/wiki/Florida_pompano: A lightning-fast schooling fish so prized for its rich, mild flesh that fillets command $17 or more, inspiring a famous New Orleans dish steamed in parchment paper. Despite most weighing under 3 pounds, it fights on the line far beyond what its size would suggest, making it a favorite of sport fishermen.
/wiki/Flying_gurnard: When threatened, this bottom-dwelling fish dramatically spreads enormous wing-like fins tipped with phosphorescent bright-blue coloration. Despite their impressive wingspan reaching 50 cm, these "wings" are used for display rather than true flight through water.
/wiki/Foureye_butterflyfish: Sports a fake eye spot ringed in white near its tail to fool predators into attacking the wrong end, while a black bar camouflages its real eye. Mates for life and can navigate the tightest coral passages by swimming sideways or completely upside down.
/wiki/French_angelfish: Juveniles run underwater cleaning stations, servicing jacks, morays, and snappers by removing parasites with a distinctive fluttering swim. Pairs mate for life and are fiercely territorial, defending their reef patch together and returning to the same hiding spot every night. Can produce knocking sounds when alarmed and features a remarkable transformation from black-and-yellow striped juvenile to golden-scaled adult.
/wiki/French_grunt: Forms massive nocturnal aggregations of thousands that emerge from coral ledges to hunt invertebrates across sandy flats. Its mouth glows bright red inside, earning it the nickname "redmouth grunt," while vivid yellow stripes decorate its compressed body. Hosts a parasitic crustacean named after Bob Marley that feeds on its blood.
/wiki/Frilled_shark: A living fossil with 300 needle-like teeth that has remained virtually unchanged for 95 million years, hunting in the deep ocean with an eel-like body. Has the longest gestation period of any vertebrate—up to 3.5 years—and can swallow prey whole with its long, flexible jaws. Practices daily vertical migration, swimming from ocean depths to the surface each night to feed.
/wiki/Frillfin_goby: Creates mental maps of its tide pool neighborhood, memorizing the exact topology so it can leap between pools without landing on lethal dry rock. This cognitive mapping ability was once thought unique to humans until the 1940s. Tiny males fiercely guard egg clusters from multiple mates inside empty shells.
/wiki/Fringed_filefish: A master of disguise that rapidly changes color to match its surroundings, often hanging head-down among seagrasses like a motionless blade. This leathery-skinned fish is nicknamed the 'cuckold' and has skin dotted with tiny fleshy spines. Males maintain harems of females who lay eggs in hidden sandy scoops, which are then vigilantly guarded by a parent.
/wiki/Gafftopsail_catfish: The male carries up to 55 fertilized eggs in his mouth for months without eating, brooding the young until they're four inches long. Armed with venomous serrated spines that can deliver painful wounds, this fighter feeds throughout the water column rather than sticking to the bottom like most catfish. Its distinctive sail-like dorsal spine resembles a ship's topsail, making it unmistakable among its relatives.
/wiki/Gag_grouper: Every individual starts life as a female, then some change sex to become males after spawning at least once—a transformation that typically happens around age 10. Males have become so rare due to fishing pressure that they now make up only 5.5% of the population, down from 15% in the 1980s. Can produce thumping sounds by vibrating its swim bladder when stressed.
/wiki/Galapagos_shark: Forms some of the densest shark populations in the Atlantic, with thousands observed at a time around isolated islands. When cornered, performs an exaggerated threat display—arching its back, gaping its jaw, and swinging its head to keep threats in view. Has been seen attacking marine iguanas and sea lions, and juveniles at Clipperton Island charged anything in the water, even striking boat bottoms in water so shallow their backs were exposed.
/wiki/Giant_cichlid: The largest cichlid on Earth, with males reaching nearly 3 feet in length—rivaling South American peacock bass for the title. Adults hunt in small pelagic packs while their young hide among shallow rocks, shifting both diet and lifestyle as they grow to enormous proportions.
/wiki/Giant_oarfish: The world's longest bony fish at up to 36 feet, this ribbon-shaped deep-sea dweller swims vertically using undulating dorsal fins and can survive losing large portions of its tail thanks to organs concentrated near its head. Its serpentine form and rare surface appearances have fueled sea monster legends for centuries.
/wiki/Golden_topminnow: This tiny surface feeder can survive in brackish waters up to 14% salinity with perfect success, but dies completely at ocean-strength salt levels. Males develop prickly contact organs during breeding season and court females by swimming in elaborate loops while bobbing their heads up and down.
/wiki/Great_northern_tilefish: This iridescent blue-green architect excavates elaborate burrows on the ocean floor, with colonies reaching densities of 13,000 burrows per square kilometer. Females spawn an astounding 2.3 million eggs per season, laying clutches every four days throughout spring and summer. Lives up to 46 years in the same burrow, continually expanding its underground home as it grows.
/wiki/Goldentail_moray: This serpentine nighttime hunter leaves its rocky lair to prowl coral reefs for crustaceans and mollusks, its brown body dotted with yellow spots that grow larger toward its golden tail. A rare color morph called the "Banana Eel" trades countless tiny spots for just a few large ones across a mostly yellow body.
/wiki/Goldline_blenny: This tiny reef dweller has an unusual survival strategy: it lives in close association with sea urchins, using their spiny defenses as protective bodyguards. Despite maxing out at just 2.4 inches, it thrives in the dangerous shallows where larger predators can't easily follow.
/wiki/Goldspotted_eel: A nocturnal hunter that prowls shallow reefs under cover of darkness, ambushing crabs and sea urchins with practiced efficiency. Despite reaching nearly 4 feet in length, it spends much of its time burrowed in sand and crevices, emerging only when the sun sets to feed.
/wiki/Atlantic_goliath_grouper: One of the largest bony fish on Earth, reaching 800 pounds and 8 feet long, yet spending its first 5-6 years hiding in mangrove nurseries. Takes over two decades to reach breeding age, making it devastatingly vulnerable to overfishing at spawning aggregations. Protected by total fishing moratoriums since 1990, though Florida recently approved limited harvests starting in 2023.
/wiki/Gray_angelfish: Juveniles operate cleaning stations on reefs, removing parasites from larger fish like tiny underwater barbers. Adults can release up to 75,000 eggs in a single spawning event, swimming belly-to-belly with their mate above deep reefs at dawn. Their diet consists primarily of sponges, though they've been known to cause ciguatera poisoning when consumed by humans.
/wiki/Gray_snapper: This crafty predator has been observed systematically waiting beneath bat colonies to snatch falling prey at cave entrances. Can change color from bright red to copper, and its wariness of divers increases dramatically with age and size.
/wiki/Graysby: This secretive reef dweller starts life as female and transforms into a harem-guarding male at age 4 or 5. A nocturnal hunter that patrols just half an acre of territory, staying close to hiding spots during daylight hours. Sports distinctive spots that can shift between black and white along its back.
/wiki/Great_barracuda: An ambush predator that explodes from stillness to 27 mph in sudden bursts, using razor-sharp fangs to snatch prey before they know what hit them. Known to herd schools of fish into shallow water and guard them like a living larder for later meals. That mysterious follower shadowing your snorkel? Probably just hoping you'll leave scraps.
/wiki/Great_hammerhead: This apex predator uses its bizarre hammer-shaped head as both a metal detector and a weapon, pinning stingrays to the seafloor before devouring them. One specimen was found with 96 venomous stingray spines lodged in its mouth, seemingly unbothered. Its massive fins command top dollar in shark fin soup, driving populations toward extinction.
/wiki/Great_white_shark: Takes 26-33 years to reach sexual maturity and can live over 70 years, making it one of the longest-lived cartilaginous fish. Despite its fearsome reputation from Jaws, humans aren't preferred prey—fewer than 10 fatal attacks occur worldwide each year. Can dive to depths of 3,900 feet and has only one natural predator: the orca.
/wiki/Greater_amberjack: The largest member of the jack family, this powerful predator earned the nickname "reef donkey" for its stubborn, bulldozing fight when hooked. A single female can release up to 59 million eggs in one spawning season, making it one of the ocean's most prolific fish.
/wiki/Green_moray: The largest moray in the tropical Atlantic, its distinctive green hue comes not from pigment but from a protective layer of mucus that coats its darker skin. So elusive that visual surveys may undercount populations by up to 400%, and toxic enough to cause ciguatera poisoning if eaten.
/wiki/Green_razorfish: Named for its stunning appearance, this slender wrasse earned the title 'beautiful' in its scientific name. Its razor-thin profile helps it slice through water and burrow into sandy seafloors to escape predators.
/wiki/Green_swordtail: The male's elongated tail sword doesn't just look impressive—it directly accelerates female puberty while suppressing rival males' development. This live-bearing fish has become an invasive pest across multiple continents thanks to its ability to reproduce at lightning speed, establishing feral populations from Australia to Madagascar.
/wiki/Grey_triggerfish: Blows jets of water at the seafloor to unearth sand dollars, then flips them over repeatedly until they land upside-down for the kill. Can wedge itself into crevices using a special locking spine that functions like a biological deadbolt. Males maintain harems by defending multiple sandy nests where females guard hundreds of thousands of tiny eggs.
/wiki/Gulf_flounder: This master of camouflage lies flat on the ocean floor with both eyes on its left side, ambushing prey with razor-sharp teeth. Juveniles hide in seagrass beds while adults migrate offshore to spawn in winter, with females growing faster and larger than males. A popular sportfish that falls victim to invasive lionfish in a role reversal of predator and prey.
/wiki/Gulf_killifish: This hardy minnow survives extreme conditions from freshwater to twice-ocean salinity, and temperatures from near-freezing to bathwater-hot. Now serves as a living test subject for oil spill research, helping scientists understand how crude oil affects marine life in America's most vulnerable coastal waters.
/wiki/Gulf_menhaden: Powers the second-largest fishery in the United States by weight, yet this silvery filter-feeder's reach extends far beyond the nets—it sustains entire coastal ecosystems as a crucial bait fish. Spawns offshore in winter, with larvae drifting for miles on ocean currents before settling into estuarine nurseries as juveniles.
/wiki/Gulf_of_Mexico_fringed_sole: A bottom-dwelling flatfish that survived the Deepwater Horizon oil spill, lurking at depths up to 614 feet. Often accidentally caught in shrimp trawls, this fringed sole represents the unseen biodiversity of the Gulf's deeper waters.
/wiki/Gulf_pipefish: The male carries fertilized eggs in a specialized brood pouch for two weeks, collecting clutches from multiple females after an elaborate courtship dance that involves bobbing to the surface and intertwining bodies. This tiny armored fish feeds almost exclusively on copepods when young, switching to amphipods and shrimp as it grows—though most won't live to see their first birthday.
/wiki/Gulf_surgeonfish: Armed with razor-sharp scalpel-like spines on its tail that give surgeonfish their name, this species can deliver painful defensive slashes when threatened. Some scientists consider it the same species as the ocean surgeonfish, making its true identity a subject of taxonomic debate.
/wiki/Gulf_toadfish: Widely despised by anglers for swallowing hooks and stealing bait meant for game fish, this bottom-dwelling opportunist lurks near structure waiting for easy meals. Despite its dangerous appearance and common belief otherwise, it lacks the toxic excretions found in its toadfish cousins.
/wiki/Guppy: Introduced worldwide to combat malaria by eating mosquito larvae, though often harming native fish instead. Females choose mates based on orange coloration that signals superior foraging skills—the same carotenoids found in their favorite fruit. Males pass their elaborate patterns directly through Y-chromosome genes, creating endless color variations in just two generations per year.
/wiki/Hairy_blenny: A surprisingly fierce predator that tackles prey far beyond its weight class, including spiny sea urchins and brittle stars. Thrives in water so shallow you could wade through it, rarely venturing deeper than a swimming pool's shallow end.
/wiki/Hardhead_catfish: Males carry fertilized eggs in their mouths for up to 11 weeks without eating, protecting the brood while staying mobile. May use primitive sonar-like echolocation by emitting low-frequency sounds to detect nearby obstacles. Sharp, venomous spines in its dorsal and pectoral fins can pierce through tennis shoes.
/wiki/Harlequin_bass: A striking black-and-white patterned hunter that swallows crustaceans whole with its oversized mouth. This synchronous hermaphrodite possesses both male and female organs simultaneously and can even fertilize its own eggs—a rare trait among vertebrates.
/wiki/Highfin_carpsucker: Sports an exceptionally long dorsal fin that gives this silvery bottom-feeder its name. Females carry up to 62,000 eggs and play a crucial role in river ecosystems by cleaning sandy and gravelly bottoms, maintaining habitat quality for prized game fish.
/wiki/Hickory_shad: This toothy predator spawns in rivers but spends most of its life at sea, carrying enough fat reserves to fuel its entire upstream migration without eating. Once overlooked in favor of its cousin the American shad, it's now become the fourth-most targeted fish by coastal anglers despite only being available for two months each year.
/wiki/Hogchoker: Named for its ability to suction-cup itself to a hog's mouth when fed as 'trash fish,' this flatfish clings to surfaces using its belly like a living sticky note. Marketed misleadingly as 'freshwater flounder' in pet stores, it actually thrives in brackish water and migrates seasonally between fresh and saltwater to spawn.
/wiki/Hogfish: This sex-changing wrasse uses its elongated pig-like snout to root through sediment for buried crustaceans, giving it its barnyard name. Starting life as female, it transforms into a male around age three, with dominant males controlling harems of females in their territory. Masters of active camouflage, they seamlessly blend against coral and sand while hunting molluscs and sea urchins.
/wiki/Honeycomb_moray: Named for the distinctive honeycomb pattern covering its body, this snake-like predator lurks in reef crevices waiting to ambush prey with razor-sharp teeth. Can grow up to three feet long and uses its muscular body to navigate tight spaces where other predators can't follow.
/wiki/Horned_searobin: Named for the soldier-like spines jutting from its snout like horns, the male's first dorsal spines can stretch all the way to its tail fin. This rosy red bottom-dweller sports elaborate yellow racing stripes and prowls sandy ocean floors hunting shrimp, crabs, and even fish eggs with its small but effective mouth.
/wiki/Horse-eye_jack: Named for its unusually large eyes covered by a transparent eyelid, this powerful swimmer can reach over 3 feet long and schools around scuba divers, seemingly fascinated by their exhaled bubbles. Despite being prized by anglers, it's a dangerous carrier of ciguatera toxin potent enough to cause severe illness in humans who consume it.
/wiki/Houndfish: The largest needlefish, growing up to 5 feet long with a crocodile-like beak that becomes a lethal weapon when it leaps from the water at frightened or light-attracted prey. Known to cause severe puncture wounds to fishermen and snorkelers, including cases of collapsed lungs and neck injuries. Juvenile teeth uniquely point forward, distinguishing it from all other needlefish species.
/wiki/Humpback_grouper: Juveniles swim upside-down with striking polka-dot patterns, while adults transform from female to male as they age and dominate. A single individual speared off Florida in 2012 raised fears of a lionfish-style invasion from this Indo-Pacific native. This humpbacked ambush predator is so overexploited in Southeast Asian markets that Australia designated it a no-take species.
/wiki/Indigo_Hamlet: A master of disguise that can switch between male and female roles during spawning, this deep blue reef dweller may mimic harmless chromis fish to get closer to unsuspecting prey. Despite being wary, it often circles back to investigate stationary divers with curious boldness.
/wiki/Inshore_lizardfish: A cigar-shaped ambush predator that buries itself in sand with only its eyes visible, waiting to strike passing fish and shrimp with a mouth full of needle-like teeth. Despite living up to nine years, most end up as discarded bycatch in shrimp trawls across the Gulf of Mexico.
/wiki/Jack_Dempsey_(fish): Named after the legendary 1920s boxer for its aggressive attitude and powerful jaw, this devoted parent pre-chews food to feed its young. Both mother and father guard their territory fiercely, turning almost black during breeding season while their normally iridescent blue and gold scales fade to signal their protective mood.
/wiki/Jack-knifefish: Sports a dramatically tall dorsal fin and three distinctive black bands, the last extending like a ribbon from fin-tip to tail. Successfully bred in captivity for the aquarium trade, it feeds on tiny invertebrates along coastal reefs. Despite being easy to collect and highly valued by aquarium enthusiasts, wild populations remain stable across its wide range.
/wiki/Jolthead_porgy: Named for its feeding technique of jolting mollusks off rocks with powerful head strikes. This brassy silver fish sports a distinctive blue line under each eye and an orange-rimmed mouth. Can grow to nearly 25 pounds, making it one of the largest members of its genus.
/wiki/Keel-jawed_needlefish: This sleek predator patrols tropical and subtropical waters with distinctive keeled jaws that slice through the surface like scissors. Can launch itself clear out of the water at high speeds, making it both a challenging game fish and an occasional hazard to boaters who've been struck by airborne needlefish.
/wiki/Keeltail_needlefish: Resembling a freshwater gar with its needle-like jaws, this offshore predator sports dramatic flat keels on either side of its tail like racing fins. Its eggs attach to floating debris with specialized tendrils, drifting across tropical seas until they hatch into schooling juveniles.
/wiki/King_mackerel: Matches the legendary wahoo in raw speed, ripping through blistering runs that make it one of the most sought-after gamefish in the Atlantic. Females can reach 90 pounds while males rarely exceed 11 pounds—any king over 15 pounds is almost certainly female. So mercury-laden that it's one of only four fish the FDA warns pregnant women to completely avoid.
/wiki/Knobbed_porgy: Born female and transforms into male during its lifetime, developing a distinctive humped forehead as it ages. This deep-bodied fish can live nearly two decades, hunting mollusks and sea urchins along rocky ocean floors. The violet-snouted beauty switches sexes at maturity, around 30-50 cm in length.
/wiki/Lagoon_triggerfish: Swims forwards, backwards, and hovers using wave-like fin motions with the precision of a helicopter. Fiercely territorial mothers guard their eggs for half a day, fanning them constantly—if removed, virtually all eggs are lost to predators. Has trichromatic color vision like humans, with specialized cone cells that function as independent color channels.
/wiki/Lake_chubsucker: This bottom-dwelling omnivore survives on a diet that's up to 70% vegetation, making it unusual among its carnivorous relatives. Coal ash spills and agricultural runoff have caused its swimming performance to deteriorate even when mortality rates remain unchanged. Scatters up to 20,000 eggs randomly over underwater plants in a breeding frenzy that lasts just two weeks.
/wiki/Lancer_dragonet: This sexually dimorphic bottom-dweller roams both sides of the Atlantic, from Cape Hatteras to remote islands like St. Helena and Ascension. Named after pioneering ichthyologist Spencer Fullerton Baird, it glides over sandy seafloors and seagrass beds at depths ranging from just beneath the surface to nearly 300 feet.
/wiki/Lane_snapper: This nocturnal reef predator sports distinctive yellow racing stripes and stays loyal to its home turf after adulthood—except when it's time to spawn. Its tasty white meat makes it a prized catch, but beware: larger specimens can accumulate ciguatera toxin potent enough to poison humans. Shrimp fisheries accidentally scoop up thousands of juveniles, driving steep population declines across much of its range.
/wiki/Lantern_bass: This tiny reef dweller practices a bizarre social system where the largest fish acts as the dominant male while smaller hermaphrodites can switch roles during spawning. Juveniles take shelter inside empty conch shells, while adults stake out territories in turtle grass beds from shallow waters down to 260 feet deep.
/wiki/Largehead_hairtail: This silvery predator lacks a tail fin entirely, instead tapering to a thin whip-like point that gives it a living sword appearance. Armed with long fang-like teeth, it performs reverse vertical migration as an adult—descending to hunt during the day and rising at night. The sixth most-caught fish species globally, with over 1.3 million tonnes landed annually.
/wiki/Least_puffer: When threatened, this tiny fish inflates its belly with water like a living balloon. Its teeth have fused into a parrot-like beak split down the middle, creating four bony plates perfect for crushing prey. The smallest member of its genus, it's so common in muddy bays that shrimpers catch them by accident constantly.
/wiki/Leatherjack: A voracious predator that hunts in packs alongside larger species, devouring small fish and shrimp with relentless appetite. Once considered inedible, large-scale farming has brought this mild, oily-fleshed fish to market shelves. Juveniles hiding in sea grass beds sometimes fall prey to blue swimmer crabs in an ironic reversal of fortune.
/wiki/Lebranche_mullet: A detritus-feeding fish so commercially valuable that its eggs are harvested as a delicacy commanding premium prices. Produces several million pelagic eggs per spawning season, with females maturing later but outnumbering males in the population. Ventures from saltwater into brackish and even freshwater environments while grazing on algae and organic debris.
/wiki/Lemon_shark: Named for its yellow camouflage coloring, this coastal predator hunts at night using electroreceptors in its head to detect prey's electrical pulses in complete darkness. Returns faithfully to the same nursery sites year after year, with juveniles forming size-matched social groups that enhance survival through shared knowledge of predators and prey.
/wiki/Lesser_electric_ray: This sluggish ray generates up to 37 volts from elongated organs running through its disc-shaped body, using electric shocks to stun prey and defend against threats. Despite catastrophic population crashes to just 2% of historical levels in some areas, it remains a nocturnal hunter of worms and small fish in the surf zone.
/wiki/Lichen_moray_eel: Named for its mottled, lichen-like camouflage pattern that makes it nearly invisible against coral and rock. This secretive predator lurks in reef crevices, striking at prey with lightning-fast jaws lined with sharp, backward-curved teeth designed to prevent escape.
/wiki/Lined_seahorse: The male carries fertilized eggs in a specialized pouch and performs ritual dances with his mate every morning to reaffirm their monogamous bond. After a partner dies, the survivor often never finds another mate in its short lifetime. Its independently moving eyes can scan surroundings while remaining perfectly still, ambushing prey by creating a vacuum that sucks food directly into its tubular snout.
/wiki/Little_tunny: Rockets through the water at 40 mph on blistering runs that strip fishing line, yet is so oily and strong-tasting that it's mainly used as shark bait. Despite lacking a swim bladder, it must swim constantly to stay afloat, powered by a torpedo-shaped body built for relentless speed.
/wiki/Longbill_spearfish: Named after a Florida taxidermist, this sleek ocean predator rockets through tropical waters hunting tuna and needlefish with its distinctive spear-like bill. Despite reaching over 8 feet long, the heaviest one ever recorded weighed just 128 pounds—built for speed, not bulk.
/wiki/Longfin_damselfish: This underwater farmer cultivates its own algae gardens with the help of domesticated mysid shrimp, which fertilize the crops in exchange for protection from predators. The relationship represents one of the rare examples of animal domestication in the fish world, creating a sophisticated aquatic agricultural system.
/wiki/Longfin_mako_shark: This slow-cruising shark feeds its unborn young with unfertilized eggs in the womb, giving birth to pups over 3 feet long. Despite reaching 14 feet and possessing the trademark speed-adaptations of its family, its long pectoral fins suggest a more leisurely lifestyle than its famous shortfin cousin. Attracted to chemical lights and armed with knife-like teeth, it hunts schooling fish in the twilight zone of the deep ocean.
/wiki/Longlure_frogfish: The fastest strike in the animal kingdom—this ambush predator can inhale prey in just 0.006 seconds, faster than a blink. Disguised as a sponge with fake eye-spots, it "walks" on stalked fins and uses a wiggling lure to trick fish into swimming within range. Can swallow prey larger than itself and spawn eggs in a buoyant mucus raft that drifts across the ocean.
/wiki/Longspine_squirrelfish: Defends its territory with distinctive "grunt" and "staccato" sounds, even mobbing predators like moray eels in coordinated acoustic attacks. Those enormous eyes aren't just for show—they help it hunt zoobenthos during nocturnal feeding sessions in the deep reef.
/wiki/Lookdown: Sports dramatically elongated fin rays that give it a scythe-like silhouette, making it a prized catch for public aquariums. Its deep, laterally-compressed body and concave head profile create one of the most distinctive shapes in Atlantic waters. Young individuals display faint vertical bars that mysteriously fade as they mature.
/wiki/Mahi-mahi: One of the ocean's fastest fish, clocking speeds up to 57 mph while hunting flying fish and squid. Females spawn up to a million eggs at a time and both sexes reach sexual maturity in just 4-5 months, making them among the fastest-growing fish in the sea. Their dazzling colors shift through multiple hues when pulled from water before fading to yellow-grey.
/wiki/Man-of-war_fish: Lives fearlessly among the deadly tentacles of the Portuguese man o' war, nibbling on its host while using extraordinary agility and 41 vertebrae to dodge stings. Despite having tenfold resistance to the toxin, it still carefully avoids the largest tentacles and relies on acrobatic swimming rather than protective mucus to survive.
/wiki/Manytooth_conger: A bottom-dwelling predator that makes its home in the warm tropical waters of coral reefs, hunting from rocky crevices at depths up to 180 feet. Despite reaching lengths over three feet, this serpentine fish is targeted by subsistence fisheries throughout its Caribbean range.
/wiki/Marbled_grouper: Juveniles of this secretive grouper hide among the venomous spines of sea urchins for protection. Adults undergo a dramatic color transformation from black with white blotches to yellowish-brown with dark spots. This nervous fish darts away at the slightest approach, spending its days lurking in deep caves up to 250 meters down.
/wiki/Marbled_moray: This secretive reef dweller hides in rocky crevices during the day, revealing its distinctive marbled pattern only when hunting at night. Despite its serpentine appearance and sharp teeth, it prefers to avoid confrontation and feeds primarily on small crustaceans and fish.
/wiki/Masked_puffer: Sports a striking black mask like a tiny aquatic bandit and trades its usual solitary lifestyle for surprisingly social schools when it's time to mate. Like most pufferfish, packs a toxic punch despite its charming appearance—those who sample its flesh are playing a dangerous game.
/wiki/Mayan_cichlid: Can survive in everything from freshwater to full seawater and even endure near-total oxygen deprivation for two hours by simply shutting down. This invasive species from Mexico now thrives in the Everglades, armed with protrusible jaws and an appetite for anything from snails to smaller fish.
/wiki/Megamouth_shark: One of the most sensational discoveries in 20th-century marine biology, this mysterious filter-feeder swims through the depths with its enormous mouth agape, rising toward the surface each night to follow plankton migrations. So rare that fewer than 100 have ever been seen since 1976, it was completely unknown to science until one became tangled in a Navy ship's anchor near Hawaii.
/wiki/Mekong_giant_catfish: Once held the Guinness World Record for largest freshwater fish, this toothless herbivore can grow to 10 feet long and 770 pounds in just six years. Young fish have barbels and teeth that completely disappear by adulthood, leaving a smooth, featureless mouth perfect for grazing algae off submerged rocks.
/wiki/Metallic_lanternfish: Males and females of this deep-sea fish glow in completely different places—males flash brilliant dorsal scales while females light up ventrally. These tiny bioluminescent fish cruise the dark Atlantic depths, their metallic bodies adorned with glowing scales that develop earlier in males than females.
/wiki/Midas_cichlid: A powerhouse fighter with crushing jaws that shouldn't share a tank with anything it can bully. Wild populations have quietly evolved into dozens of distinct species within isolated volcanic crater lakes, making them a textbook example of sympatric speciation. Those vibrant gold and orange specimens in pet stores? Generations of selective breeding—wild ones are mostly drab olive-brown.
/wiki/Midnight_parrotfish: Takes up to 28,000 bites per day as a juvenile, scraping algae with a parrot-like beak that also grinds coral into sand. Schools with blue tang for camouflage protection, its dark and light blue patches perfectly matching the fish and sunlight rays. Sometimes raids damselfish nests in groups of 30, overwhelming guards to steal both algae and eggs.
/wiki/Mirrorwing_flyingfish: Uses wing-like pectoral fins to glide above the ocean surface, escaping predators in spectacular flying leaps. Spawns year-round by attaching eggs to floating debris using specialized filaments that act like natural anchors. Found in tropical waters worldwide, though curiously absent from Africa's Benguela Current for reasons unknown.
/wiki/Misty_grouper: This deep-sea giant haunts the continental shelf edge at depths up to 1,300 feet, sporting chocolate-brown coloring with distinctive prison-stripe bars that earned it the name "convict grouper." Males can reach over 5 feet long and tip the scales at 236 pounds, making them formidable predators of squid, crustaceans, and smaller fish in the darkness below.
/wiki/Molly_miller: Sports a punk-rock mohawk of hair-like appendages on its head and oversized eyes that scan coral reefs for prey. This tiny omnivore hunts crustaceans and grazes algae in the same meal, perfectly at home in the shallow tropical waters just beneath the surface.
/wiki/Mottled_conger_moray: Also known as the viper moray for its aggressive disposition and sharp, fang-like teeth that protrude even when its mouth is closed. This reef-dwelling predator lurks in crevices by day, emerging at night to ambush crustaceans and fish with lightning-quick strikes.
/wiki/Mozambique_Tilapia: Males use urine as a chemical weapon to establish dominance and attract mates in breeding leks. This invasive mouthbrooder can thrive in everything from freshwater swamps to brackish estuaries, rapidly outcompeting native fish. Listed among the world's 100 worst invasive species, it threatens desert pupfish and Hawaiian mullet populations.
/wiki/Mummichog: The first fish ever sent to space aboard Skylab in 1973, this hardy killifish can survive in water three times saltier than the ocean and even breathe air for hours. Populations living in heavily polluted harbors have evolved resistance to industrial toxins, with 20% of their genes modified compared to clean-water relatives.
/wiki/Mutton_snapper: Returns to the exact same spawning site at the exact same lunar phase every year, gathering in massive aggregations that make them vulnerable to overfishing. Can live up to forty years and produce over 1.4 million eggs in a single spawn, with larvae migrating to shallow nursery waters within just 48 hours of hatching. Changes its body pattern from vertical bars to solid color depending on whether it's resting or swimming.
/wiki/Naked_sole: This flabby flatfish hugs the seafloor at depths up to 100 meters, camouflaging itself against soft sediments. Despite its unglamorous appearance and name, it plays an important ecological role, though trawlers accidentally scoop it up while hunting for shrimp.
/wiki/Nassau_grouper: Gathers by the thousands under the full moon at the same spawning sites year after year, making it tragically easy to overfish. Can inhale prey whole with its massive mouth and changes color from tawny to pink depending on water depth. Once thriving around Caribbean reefs, over a third of its spawning sites have vanished entirely.
/wiki/Neon_tetra: This tiny Amazonian fish changes its electric blue stripe from brilliant cyan to deep indigo at night through guanine crystals in its cells. Despite hailing from the extreme acidity of blackwater streams, over 1.8 million are imported monthly to American aquariums, making it one of the planet's most traded fish.
/wiki/Dusky_sergeant: A devoted parent, males of this species stand guard over their eggs, constantly fanning them with fresh oxygen until they hatch. This tropical damselfish thrives in the shallow rocky waters of the eastern Pacific, from El Salvador to Peru.
/wiki/Night_shark: A deepwater predator with glowing green eyes that performs nightly vertical migrations, rising from depths of 1,200 feet to hunt squid and fish in shallower waters after dark. Despite being highly valued for its fins, most caught off Brazil contain unsafe mercury levels. Fast-growing pups add 38% of their body length in their first year—a survival strategy to quickly outgrow the most dangerous period of their lives.
/wiki/Nile_perch: This invasive giant can reach 200 kg and is considered one of the world's 100 worst invasive species, causing the extinction of hundreds of native fish in Lake Victoria. Its high fat content revolutionized regional food processing, driving massive deforestation as communities switched from sun-drying to smoking. Ancient Egyptians mummified thousands of these fish in worship of the goddess Neith.
/wiki/Nile_tilapia: A prolific breeder that can spawn within months of birth, this African transplant has become one of the world's most invasive fish species. Males dig circular nests with their mouths and turn bright red during breeding season, while females carry eggs in their mouths for nearly two weeks. Despite eating mosquito larvae, its explosive population growth devastates native ecosystems wherever it's introduced.
/wiki/Northern_puffer: Nicknamed "sugar toads" in the Chesapeake Bay, these defensive fish inflate into spiky balls by gulping water. Using their beak-like mouths, they flip blue crabs upside-down with jets of water and attack the vulnerable underside before their prey can recover.
/wiki/Northern_snakehead: Can breathe air and survive out of water for days, allowing it to wriggle overland to new bodies of water. A single female lays 100,000 eggs per year and guards them fiercely, enabling populations to double in just 15 years. Introduced accidentally to US waters, this invasive predator triggered pond poisonings and emergency containment efforts to protect native ecosystems.
/wiki/Nurse_shark: Generates the most powerful suction force ever recorded in aquatic vertebrates, strong enough to inhale prey from deep within reef crevices. Despite their docile, bottom-dwelling nature, they rank fourth in documented shark bites on humans—usually because divers get too comfortable around them. Returns to the exact same breeding grounds year after year, one of the few shark species with proven mating site fidelity.
/wiki/Ocean_sunfish: One of the world's largest bony fish, weighing up to 5,100 pounds, yet it lacks a tail—its body ends in a lumpy pseudotail that makes it look like a swimming head. Despite appearing to drift lazily at the surface, it actively hunts at depths over 600 feet and can leap 10 feet out of the water to dislodge parasites.
/wiki/Acanthurus_bahianus: This blue-gray algae grazer was once thought to roam north to Massachusetts, but genetic studies revealed those fish were actually a different species entirely. Armed with sharp spines on its tail like a surgeon's scalpel, it schools with other tangs while patrolling Brazilian coral reefs from tropical Maranhão to temperate Santa Catarina.
/wiki/Oceanic_whitetip_shark: Jacques Cousteau called it "the most dangerous of all sharks." Slow-moving but ruthlessly opportunistic, it's believed responsible for hundreds of deaths from the USS Indianapolis disaster in 1945. Those distinctive long, rounded fins earned it the Latin name "longimanus"—long fingers.
/wiki/Ocellated_frogfish: A master of camouflage that sits motionless on the seafloor, using a modified dorsal spine as a fishing rod to lure prey within striking distance. Its fins are often fringed with red, and its ability to blend into coral and rock makes it nearly invisible to both predators and the small fish it ambushes.
/wiki/Ocellated_moray: Named for its striking honeycomb pattern of eye-like spots that cover its serpentine body. This nocturnal predator lurks in rocky crevices by day, emerging at night to ambush fish and crustaceans with lightning-quick strikes from its powerful jaws.
/wiki/Okefenokee_pygmy_sunfish: This tiny olive-green fish with blue sparkles measures barely over an inch long, making it one of North America's smallest sunfish. Males transform into shimmering black beauties during breeding season while females remain camouflaged in tan. Despite its diminutive size, it thrives in extreme temperature swings from near-freezing to bath-water warm.
/wiki/Orange-spine_surgeonfish: Armed with two bright orange forward-hooked spines on its tail that strike approaching predators, this coral reef dweller harbors unique Epulopiscium bacteria in its gut that help digest algae. Its distinctive black face mask and orange lips make it one of the most recognizable unicornfishes in tropical waters.
/wiki/Orangespotted_filefish: This reef-dweller sports a massive spine on its head that folds neatly into a groove like a switchblade when not in use. It survives by munching on sponges and algae while hiding among tall corals, its body adorned with distinctive orange spots and bold brown bands.
/wiki/Orangespotted_goby: Lives in a symbiotic partnership with snapping shrimp, acting as a sentinel guard at the entrance of the shrimp's burrow while enjoying free housing. The goby watches for predators while the nearly-blind shrimp digs and maintains their shared home in the sandy seafloor.
